Itchy Coo has been producing just those kinds of books for years."Irsquom really proud to have been part of that.With the Wimpy Kid series already spanning  books, therersquos plenty of opportunity for Thomas to revisit Greg Heffley and Westmore Middle School in the future but for now, the writer is keeping his feet firmly on the ground.He added: ldquoIrsquom just really glad that children and adults are getting the chance to reconnect with a fantastic book, and to do so in their own tongue."To be involved in something like that, helping young people connect with literature and their own language at the same time, I donrsquot think any writer can ask for more.

title: programme-of-events-published-as-gala-remembers
story: A PACKED programme of entertainment and educational events are about to take place as Gala Remembers.The ambitious initiative marks  years since the end of World War I as well as Galashielsrsquo role in the conflict which claimed the lives of  men from the town.A series of community organisations have come together, led by community group Energise Galashiels Trust, to host the exhibitions, lectures, film screenings, live music, light displays, street art and acts of remembrance throughout October and November.Alongside the Remembrance activities, there is plenty of entertainment on offer, with the Pavilion Cinema holding a World War I season with films such as the critically acclaimed War Horse being screened.A World War I themed afternoon tea and dance will be hosted in the Focus Centre.And the Royal British Legion will provide a WWI cabaret as well as a Festival of Remembrance being held in the Volunteer Hall.Mike Gray, chair of Energise Galashiels Trust, told the Border : ldquoWorld War I had a devastating impact on towns such as Galashiels, which lost seven per cent of its male population as a result of the conflict."However, it also provided a number of fascinating stories which have inspired films, books, research and exhibitions.During the run up to Armistice there will also be a number of educational opportunities with four lectures looking at the role of animals, hospitals, and both Canada and Scotland rugby internationals during the war.Genealogy research will also take place, while primary school pupils will get the chance to learn more about the conflict.Old Gala House will also host a series of exhibitions alongside other locations in the Borders including Abbotsford House Visitor Centre.Bill White, chair of Gala Remembers  partnership said: ldquoAs part of a respectful commemoration to World War I, Gala Remembers  has a wide iety of events being offered by the ious community organisations involved, with the aim that a legacy will be created to continue this project in the future as Galashiels undergoes a major regeneration.Community groups involved in Gala Remembers  include Borders Family History Society, Boys Brigade, Energise Galashiels Trust, Ex- Braw Lads and Lasses Association, Focus Centre, Focus Centre Crochet Class, Galashiels Academy and Primary Schools, Galashiels Camera Club, Galashiels Community Council, Langlee Community Choir, Old Gala Club, One Accord Chorus, Royal British Legion Scotland Galashiels branch and Works+.Other contributors include Abbotsford House, BQ plc, Ballantynes of Walkerburn, BID for Galashiels, Borders College, Booker plc, Car Parts  U, Criminal Justice Team, Gala RFC, Live Borders, McGowan Marketing, Morrison  Murray, Nikirsquos Bar, Paper Violet, Pavilion Cinema, Salmon Inn, Scotlandrsquos War -, Scottish Borders Council, Scottish National Textiles Collection and WSZ Joiners.Programmes highlighting the ious events have now been published and are available from local outlets.

title: blooming-marvellous-communities-celebrated-by-floral-gateway
story: TOWNS and villages across the Borders have been celebrated at the annual Floral Gateway awards.For the th year, Scottish Borders Council hosted a ceremony to recognise the communities who have blossomed over the summer.Berwickshire village Westruther was named the Champion of Champions after claiming the Wee Village category last year.After taking over responsibility for maintenance of all the bedding plants and grass cutting the residents have transformed their village.Grace Donaldson of the Westruther Floral Gateway Group said: ldquoIt is wonderful to win this and to get some recognition for all the volunteers.ldquoWe first entered in  and to win the Champion of Champions for a first time is a wonderful feeling.ldquoIt is a community effort - we have around  of us but without the help of farmers and others we couldnrsquot do what we do.Taking the Town prize for  was Jedburgh, with Lauder being named best Large Village.Ayton was named the best Small Village of  and Birgham claimed the Wee Village title.During the ceremony there were a number of other community awards presented for towns and villages who have played their part to keep the Borders thriving.And Lauder and Eyemouth were also congratulated for picking up Beautul Scotland Awards earlier this month.Councillor Sandy Aitchison, the Executive member for Neighbourhoods, told the ceremony: ldquoWe need to thank the ious In Bloom groups across the Borders who do fantastic work to help maintain our region all year round.ldquoIt is also great to see the extra efforts made by some groups to improve their communities which have led to national recognition, while the overall winners Westruther have shown tremendous initiative to become largely self-sufficient in terms of maintaining their community.ldquoThis year has seen a Neighbourhoods Review which focussed on changes to grass cutting maintenance and bedding plant provision."We need to do thing dferently due to the signicant financial challenges we are now facing, with a focus also on improving the bioersity of the Borders."Congratulations to all the winners of a Floral Gateway award.Healthmatic sponsored the main categories of the Floral Gateway Awards, with the Champion of Champions receiving a pound voucher and the other category winners picking up a pound voucher each.The Quality of Le winners picked up a pound voucher each sponsored by the local authority and the Clean and Tidy winners received a new litter dog waste bin for their communities.Champion of Champions: st Westruther nd Hawick, Coldstream and ColdinghamTown: st Jedburgh nd Eyemouth rd KelsoLarge Village: st Lauder nd ChirnsideSmall Village: st Ayton nd Greenlaw rd AncrumWee Village:st Birgham nd Morebattle rd BurnmouthBorder Bioersity: st AncrumClean and Tidy: st Lauder and WestrutherQuality of Le: st Coldstream, Lauder and JedburghWelcome Award: st Broughton and Hume

title: more-needs-to-be-done-to-put-brakes-on-melrose-speedsters-say-residents
story: FED up Melrose residents say more needs to be done to put the brakes on speedsters in the town.At last weekrsquos community council meeting, members were told that drivers are often seen doing double the  miles per hour limit. And one local said he would like to see electronic signs erected on one of the main routes into the town.The member of the public told the meeting: ldquoI have recently moved back to Melrose ndash to Waverley Road, right where the limit drops down to mph.ldquoEvery day you see cars speeding in and out of the town and my main concern is that someone could get hurt during the school run when there are more children and more cars in the area.ldquoI would say around  per cent of drivers actually adhere to the limit.ldquoIf the speeding was marginal, I would not be sat here talking about it, but the fact is, many are driving in and out of the town at speeds of up to  and mph. It is a big problem.ldquoI lived in Newcastle for a while and in Ponteland there are electronic signs which have sensors on them. The sign flashes redthe driver is breaking the limit.ldquoI would like to see something similar introduced here. It might not stop speeding altogether, butdrivers see the sign flashing red, they have to make a conscious decision on whether to carry on at the speed they are going at or slow down.The speed limit increases from mph to mph on Waverley Road, heading out of the town, before eventually becoming mph near the Melrose roundabout.William Windram, chairman of Melrose and District Community Council said: ldquoSpeeding has been an issue and we did a lot of work a few years ago to get that mph limit put in, because before that there was nothing in place ndash meaning drivers coming into the town had to drop from mph to mph.Community councillors asked local policeman Calum Wilsonofficers could monitor the road or a carry out a speeding survey.PC Wilson said: ldquoI think a speeding survey would have to be conducted by the council, but I will certainly ask the road policing officers to keep an eye on the road.

title: sheep-dip-inventors-historic-borders-pet-store-on-the-market
story: BRITAINrsquoS oldest pet supply store is on the market.The Borders business, which was founded in , has only had four owners during its illustrious -years.And offers are currently being taken from anyone hoping to become the fth.W E Howden was first established in Coldstream by George Wilson, the inventor of sheep dip.And the High Street store, which was last refitted in , contains many of the original fittings, including a B-listed frontage, the original dispensary counter and hand-crafted storage units.The current owner and landlord, Rob Smith, has decided to retire after being at the helm for the last  years.He told us: ldquoThe craftsmanship is quite something and entirely unique.ldquoThe new owner will be taking over a business in good shape with plenty of growth opportunities, particularly in our line of own brand pet food.W E Howden is being sold jointly by the Edinburgh commercial agency branch of Allied Surveyors and Borders based Solicitors and Estate Agents, Hastings Legal.Iain Mercer, Allied Surveyorsrsquo director of commercial agency, said: ldquoThis is an extremely rare and unique opportunity to purchase W E Howden and continue the rich history and tradition of the business.ldquoThe purchaser will not only be buying the property freehold but the business goodwill, its extensive database of UK-wide clients and its own brand of dog foods ndash Coldstream Crunch and Kelso Cobbles.Offer over pound, are being invited.

title: charity-dinner-funds-marie-curie-nursing-support-for-a-year
story: HEALTH related causes in the Borders have benefitted from more than pound, of funding since the start of an annual dinner in the late s.This year the annual Borders Change Foundation Charity Dinner, held at the Carfraemill Hotel at the start of September, raised over pound, to cover the cost of a new Borders-based Marie Curie nurse.And a further pound was also raised for Doddie Weirrsquos MND charity.The dinner, organised as in previous years by James and Elaine Marjoribanks, was yet again a huge success and a great night of food and entertainment for the  guests.This years event was the th annual Charity Dinner.And following some arithmetic, it has emerged that the fundraiser has now contributed almost pound, for all sorts of health related causes in the Borders.James told the Border : "The generosity of those at the dinner was unbelievable and they all helped by buying fantastic auction prizes, that were once again very kindly donated, and contributing to the raffle."Elaine and I would like to personally thank all those that all those who, through their continued generosity, make this charity dinner the success that it really is."To be able to provide an extra Marie Curie nurse in the Borders will make such a dference to many peoplersquos lives.Mr Marjoribanks also acknowledged the help of well-known chef Gary Moore for his input into the first eight dinners when it was known as the Borders Charity Dinner.The funding from this months dinner will allow for a Marie Curie nurse to operate entirely in the Scottish Borders for the next  months.Marie Curie Community Fundraiser for the Borders Angela Davidson was full of praise for the Borders Change Foundation Charity Dinner.She told us: "Last year in The Scottish Borders, our local Marie Curie nurses provided care to  patients and carried out over  visits."A visit is normally an overnight nine-hour sht, starting at pm and working through the night, finishing at am."This equates to  hours of nursing care at a cost to the charity of pound per hour."This means that it cost Marie Curie pound, to provide our service in The Borders alone - that is why this fantastic donation from the Borders Change Foundation means such a lot and will make a tremendous dference in the Borders.

title: conker-bout-has-not-been-conquered-say-organisers
story: NEWS that the Peebles-based Scottish Conker Championships have been shelved is bonkers ndash according to organisers.This yearrsquos competition, which takes place next month, hit the national headlines this week after it was reported it had been cancelled due to a poor harvest.And the story was even discussed by ists on Channel rsquos Jeremy Vine show on Wednesday morning. But the Borders Forest Trust, which runs the event, says the national newspaper reports are nuts.Anna Craigen, the organisationrsquos community and education officer, told us: ldquoWe saw the national stories and were very confused to how they came about.ldquoEverything is going ahead as planned and we are very much looking forward to it.It was claimed the Tweed Green event had been called-off following Britainrsquos exceptionally hot summer, leaving a shortage of championship-standard horse chestnuts. But Anna added: ldquoI actually think the Scottish conkers this year are a lot better than in previous years.ldquoIn the past we have had to import them for the competition, but I think there are a lot of suitable ones locally this time.ldquoWe are expecting around  competitors this year ndash everyone takes it very seriously and people travel from all over the UK for the event.Organisers were forced to cancel the championships back in , due to a lack of conkers.But the group has since put together a string a successful events.Anna said: ldquoWe provide the conkers for the adult, junior and youth rounds, but contestants are free to use their own for the rogue category.ldquoWe have had people do the traditional thing and treat them in vinegar, but we have also seen conkers dipped in concrete and in E moisturising cream in the past.ldquoWe would like as many people as possible to come down to Tweed Green on the morning Saturday, October .ldquoThe competition will kick off at around am.

title: rbs-to-close-melroses-only-remaining-bank
story: MELROSE has lost its only remaining bank, following RBS decision to close the towns branch.An independent review has been carried out by chartered accountants Johnston Carmichael over the past few months.And todayit has been revealed that the Royal Bank of Scotland will close its base at the end of the High Street.The RBS said: "The bank will proceed with the closure of Melrose branch at a date to be confirmed."We will explore the options available to us to retain or replace the ATM at a suitable location."We will review our mobile branch provision in Melrose to take on board the suggestions from Johnston Carmichael. While it is not possible to confirm changes to the timetable today, subject to the necessary permissions, we will amend the mobile branch route accordingly."Ten branches were reviewed across Scotland ndash and of those, only Biggar and Barra have survived.Simon Watson, from RBS, added: "We would like to thank Johnston Carmichael for their review of  Royal Bank branches in Scotland that were due to close."These branches were selected because, unlike the other branches that were closed, they were nearly all the last bank in town and more than nine miles to the nearest alternative Royal Bank branch. We accept Johnston Carmichaelrsquos recommendations in full."Johnston Carmichael has judged that there are exceptional circumstances in Biggar and Barra and has recommended that these branches remain open ndash so they will. We also note the further recommendations for enhancements that can be made in six of the branch locations and can confirm we will be accepting these recommendations in full."The report highlights the dficult nature of branch closure decisions. We know branches are important to many communities, but equally we know that fewer and fewer people are using them as more people bank online."In every case of a branch closing we are committed to providing the best possible range of banking alternatives, including mobile branches, banking in the local post office, community bankers and remote services such as telephone banking."With todayrsquos report, we are able to say for the first time with certainty that there will be no further reviews of our branch network in the immediate future ndash until at least ."

title: digger-driver-mark-flies-the-flag-for-scotland-at-euros
story: DIGGER driver Mark Bradley is taking a dferent kind of bucket to the beach in Malaga next week.The -year-old from Peebles has qualied for the Caterpillar Operators European Championships.For three days he will rev-up against  of the best construction site drivers from around the continent at the Spanish resort.Each driver will be tested over a series of skill challenges against the clock.Mark, who works for Ewan Irvine Plant, beat off strong groundworks competition in Glasgow last month to win the Scottish qualying heat.And he is confident hersquoll be able to better the th place finish he achieved four years ago at the European Championships when they were held in Leicester.Mark told us: ldquoThere were over  operators when I finished th in Leicester and Irsquod like to think Irsquoll be able to beat that.ldquoIn previous competitions wersquove been required to lt golf balls from tees and other really dficult challenges, but you also get scored on safety and productivity as well - theres a lot to think about.ldquoIt can be really dficult but I do have good eyesight which helps me with the precision side of things.Since leaving school Mark has been behind the wheel for local construction companies.Andhersquos needing any last-minute tips ahead of the finals, he only has to look as far as his current boss, Ewan Irvine.Ewan has twice qualied for the European Championships himself ndash in  and .He told us: ldquoIrsquom confident Mark will do well.ldquoIt is quite an achievement just to reach the finals as there are a lot of good drivers out there.Mark will fly out to Malaga on Monday.And the following morning he, along with the other finalists, will be given a video presentation of the challenges which lie ahead over the next three days.The winner of the Caterpillar Operators European Championships will be announced at a dinner on the Thursday evening once the scores have been added.

title: a-is-for-apple-day
story: AN apple a day has been keeping the doctor away for generations.Later this month our favourite fruit will be celebrated with its very own day.With interest in food provenance never being higher, Live Borders and local growers are teaming up to provide everyone the opportunity to get to know their Coxs Pippin, Granny Smith and Pink Lady.Harestanes Countryside visitors centre, near Ancrum, will host Apple Day on Sunday, October  with over  ieties on display in the gallery.The event for all the family will celebrating locally grown apples and feature local food and drinks stalls, and live acoustic music from Borders Youth Music ForumHarestanes manager Michael Scott told us: ldquoInterest in growing your own fruit and veg and buying locally-sourced food has surged in the past few years.ldquoApple Day taps into that desire to discover new tastes and experiences and to meet and talk with local food growers and suppliers in person.ldquoAnd on top of that, itrsquos a celebration of autumn with music, games and fun for everyone.Harestanes has presented Apple Day, in partnership with Borders Organic Gardeners, since  centring on the regionrsquos rich heritage of small orchards, local food suppliers and the many benefits of gardening.Michael added: ldquoThere will also be fantastic, locally sourced produce in our cafeacute and country-inspired treats in our gt shop, which are both open all year round."Apple Day takes place between am and pm.

title: melrose-group-welcomes-post-office-plans
story: MEMBERS of Melrose community council have welcomed plans to move the townrsquos post office to Market Square.As previously reported, the Post Office hopes to relocate the branch to Masons of Melrose bookshop.The townrsquos postmaster, John Collins, was hoping to retire at the end of last year.But he was forced to put his leaving plans on hold after proposals to move the provision to Abbey Mill in Annay Road were abandoned ndash following objections from the local community.William Windram, chairman of Melrose and District Community Council said: ldquoIrsquom sure everyone will have now seen there are plans to move the post office to Masons of Melrose.ldquoI havenrsquot yet heard anyone say they think the move is a bad idea. I think most people agreed the last time, that Abbey Mill was just too far away for people to get to.ldquoHopefully, moving to Market Square will also increase the footfall in the bookshop too.A public event has been organised for later this year to thank Mr Collins for his  years of ldquooutstanding service to the town. A presentation will take place at the Ormiston Institute at pm on November , after the postmaster is treated to lunch by members of the community council.Meanwhile, a public consultation is currently under way to gauge opinion on the latest proposals. Clive Semple, Post Office area network change manager said: ldquoWe are making it easier for customers to get their cash, send and collect their mail and do their banking because we know how important these services are to local residents.ldquoWe are confident that this vibrant new-style post office at the heart of the local community will meet customer needs.During the six-week public review, the company will welcome feedback on any issues customers would like considered.The consultation will close on October, .People can share their views at http:postofficeviews with the branch code .

title: borders-cab-calls-for-your-food-for-thought
story: PEEBLES Citizens Advice Bureau wants locals to raise any concerns they have relating to food in Tweeddale.Bosses have created a survey to gauge public opinion on cost, choice, access and quality in the region. And it will run for the next month both online ndash www.cas.org.uk foodonthetablendash and at Peeblesrsquo CAB office.Manager Melanie Nairn said: ldquoThe people who come through our doors often talk about how hard it can be for them to put food on the table.ldquoCost is certainly a major issue for many, but it is not the only one. We also hear from people who find it hard to access affordable, good quality food locally.ldquoThe Scottish CAB network is running this national survey, and I want to make sure that people in and around Peebles form a big part of the total responses. The results will be used to inform government ministers and help shape future policy on food, so it would be a shamepeople here missed out.

title: ians-in-the-saddle-for-poppyscotland
story: A CYCLING challenge to commemorate the end of the First World War is being taken up in towns and villages across the Borders.Poppyscotland is inviting cyclists of all abilities to saddle up for , miles of riding in less than  days.And among the first to pull on his helmet is a former soldier from Hawick, who is already midway through completing the epic journey.Ian McLeod served with The Kingrsquos Own Scottish Borderers from  to  having joined up at the tender age of just  years old and nine months - the final year of so-called Boy Soldiers.He spent time in Belfast, Berlin and Inverness.Some years after leaving the Army, he joined the Territorials, where he served for  yearsThe -year-old, who is chairman of the Hawick Branch of Legion Scotland, told us: ldquoAt the Hawick Branch, we are very active in our support of the annual Scottish Poppy Appeal."We feel strongly about providing support to our veterans."Whatrsquos more, we want to say lsquothank yoursquo to all those who paid the ultimate sacrice, or were injured in conflicts, and especially on this very important anniversary of the end of the First World War."Ian began his own ,-mile challenge at the start of August.And is currently on track with his target of -miles each week.As part of the challenge, Ian will also being taking part in the annual Poppyscotland Sportive on October  - where around, riders will be taking on one of three distances ndash ,  or  miles ndash to raise funds for the charity.Ian will be tackling the longest of the routes.And he hopes to complete the , miles on October th when he will tour a series of war memorials in the Borders.Gordon Michie, head of fundraising for Poppyscotland, said: ldquoIn this important centenary year, The  Poppy Pledge has inspired groups, schools, businesses, clubs and organisations around the country to take on the challenge of raising pound, which will provide a lasting tribute to those who fell in the First World War."The fundraising efforts by Ian are nothing short of Herculean, and it is pledgers such as these that will allow us to make a step change in the scale of support Poppyscotland is able to provide those in the Armed Forces community who rely on our support today.To take part in the Poppyscotland Sportive, or for more information on the event, contact Katriona Harding, events fundraising manager at Poppyscotland, on    or email at k.harding@poppyscotland.org.uk.

title: 43-year-old-accused-of-violent-struggle-with-partner
story: A GALASHIELS man will stand trial at Selkirk Sherf Court charged with struggling violently with his partner.Barry Hogg is accused of damaging property belonging to the woman and making threatening, offensive and abusive remarks during the incident at his home in Gibsons Close on June .The -year-old pleaded not guilty to a charge of behaving in a threatening or abusive manner and a trial date was set for January  with an intermediate hearing on January .

title: entertainment-in-the-dock-at-scotts-selkirk
story: SELKIRK is set for a treble turn of tourist delights this weekend.Not only is the hugely popular Scotts Selkirk ing to the Royal Burgh on Saturday, but the town will also host the foot-tapping delights of the Selkirk Sessions as well as the new monthly Farmers Market.The busy weekend comes just as the new-look Market Place refurbishments are completed.Viv Ross from Scotts Selkirk told us: "A busy weekend is in store ndash with something for everyone."We look forward to welcoming everyone to our annual celebrations."Dozens of Souters will turn back the clock to relive the days of Scott.As well as re-enactments, period costumes and fayre from centuries gone, there will be plenty of street entertainment throughout Scotts Selkirk.Meg Dodsrsquo ever-popular Kitchen has been relocated to the High Street.The music and puppets of Crafty Beggars will share the town centre with Les Amies drsquoOnos Billy Bowler the Performing Goat.And there will be plenty Victorian childrenrsquos games, including Splat the Rat and a coconut shy, to keep the youngsters entertained.Matthew Burgess has taken over the role of Town Cryer from his late father Bob.And he will be accompanied by young drummer boys Hamish and Cameron throughout his duties.George Renton will ride into town with his penny-farthing.And this year there will also be a Scottrsquos Selkirk shop window treasure hunt ndash with forms available from the Scottrsquos Selkirk Shop.This year Sir Walter Scott will be presiding over The Tall Tale of the Tushielaw Trout, and the Lady Varnishes in his Courtroom.Down below the Courthouse Gael Force, Carlenjig, The Bogie Close Stompers, Highline Fiddlers, Bob Liddle and the Riddell Fiddles will all adorn the stage at some point during the packed programme.Viv added: "We are really looking forward to the open mic sessions where we will no doubt be treated to some exceptional music."There will also be a host of talented buskers in both the Market Place and the High Street to add to the entertainment."As well as Scotts Selkirk, the Farmers Market will operate on Saturday and throughout the weekend - from Friday evening to Sunday - Selkirk Sessions will be staged in venues across the town.

title: beast-from-east-blamed-for-abbotsford-losses
story: LAST winters extreme cold snap has taken its toll on the finances of a Borders charity.The Abbotsford Trust, which manages Sir Walter Scotts former home and estate, has now warned that it is facing a potential financial loss for .Burst pipes and snow plough charges at the beginning of the year have added to the usual costs of maintaining the house.The Trust have also blamed an underperformance of weddings and events at the venue for the forecasted deficit.Despite the outlook, Giles Ingram, Chief Executive of The Abbotsford Trust, assured that a strategy is in place for  to redress the situation.Giles said: ldquoDespite the financial forecast for , Abbotsford continues to grow and develop as a successful visitor attraction in the Borders, thanks in no small part to the amazing help we get from our volunteers and supporters.We are seeing positive trends this year which are very encouraging as we finalise our new ten year strategy and our more immediate plans for next year.ldquoOur challenge now is to minimise the losses for this year and implement our strategy for , as we continue to engage people with Scottrsquos fantastic legacy, both within the local community and further afield, especially as we look forward to celebrating his th anniversary in .The Trust also reported a small trading surplus of pound, for .The charity received donations and grants totalling pound, which was spent on the restoration of Scottrsquos woodland and riverside paths, the future restoration of Abbotsfordrsquos Portcullis Gate and garden pavilion, and a minibus to provide a free shuttle service from Tweedbank Station.The Trustrsquos trading company made a loss of pound,, which reduced the overall surplus.Abbotsford House saw a five percent increase in visits on  and met the average growth rate of . percent for Southern Scotland, although fell short of matching the rate for Scotland as a whole, which was . percent.

title: somewhere-people-can-sit-and-reflect
story: A MEMORIAL bench has been unveiled in Galashiels to honour the men from the town who made the ultimate sacrice during the Great War.As the centenary of the end of the - conflict quickly approaches special commemorations are being planned across the country.In Galashiels a programme of Remembrance has been organised to honour the  servicemen who never came home, as well as the brave sons of the town who did .Ahead of the ceremonies, concerts and lectures the Ladies Section of the Royal British Legion Galashiels Branch unveiled their Memorial Bench on Saturday.Jane Doogan from the Ladies Section told us: "We wanted to do something special this year to commemorate the men of Galashiels who gave their lives during the Great War."We also wanted the bench to mark the centenary of the end of the Great War."The distinctive black bench has been sensitively placed in the shadow of the towns War Memorial at the Lower Fountain.The bench was designed and manufactured by local company Morrison  Murray.Jane added: "The bench is somewhere people can sit and reflect."

title: council-approves-building-of-57-affordable-homes
story: SCOTTISH Borders Council has approved plans to build  affordable homes in Chirnside.Springfield Properties, which is based in Elgin, Moray, plans to build a new affordable housing estate behind Northfield terrace, with an access point on Main Street East End.The developers have also confirmed that the scheme will be taken over by a local affordable housing provider which will wholly own and operate the development.However, the proposals have been met with several objections from Chirnside residents, who raised concerns around road access, parking, housing density and the impact on local house prices.Mrs Margaret Thomson Malone, a neighbour of the proposed site, wrote: ldquoThere will be numerous traffic jams, there already are several times a day when two heavy lorries meet on a road packed with parked cars.ldquoWhere do you think all the people who would live in these houses are going to park when it snows or is covered in ice as it is every winter at some point ldquoSeveral people have now decided to sell their houses. Borlorac, two on the south side of the street opposite or adjacent to the access, and now we are considering our position, having invested thousands in renovation this development will have an adverse effect on the value of our home. Who is going to compensate us for that Mr David Jeffrey, also a close neighbour of the proposed site, wrote: ldquoThis will be an extremely dangerous access point as the street is already a disgrace to get along at all times of the day due the amount of already parked vehicles on both sides.ldquoAlso more dangerous at tea times due to the low sun. A very poor thought out idea.At a meeting of Scottish Borders Councilrsquos planning and building standards committee on Monday  October, councillors voted to approve the development despite these objections.Speaking in favour of approval, East Berwickshire councillor Helen Laing said: ldquoIrsquom broadly in favour of this development, especially with it being affordable housing, which we really need in the area.ldquoThe only concern I have here is the main road, which I drove through today actually, which does get really clogged up because of parking and traffic.ldquoAn extra  houses nearby is going to be an extra  car or so.Jedburgh and Disgrict councillor Scott Hamilton also voiced his support, saying: ldquoI think the key word we have is pressure. Pressure on the roads and pressure on the sewage system, as obviously itrsquos a smaller village and a rural location, but I think officers have addressed this issue.ldquoI think with approval of this development we need to realise it may open the door for further development of the site down the road, so I have a concern there, but Irsquom broadly in favour overall.

title: borders-exporters-hold-pre-brexit-summit
story: BORDERS businesses are being invited to a pre-Brexit meeting this week.A  of concerned bosses from companies across the region will discuss the impact leaving the EU will have.And there will also be an opportunity for questions and debate.The meeting at the Buccleuch Arms in St Boswells has been organised by the Scottish Borders Exporters Association.A spokeswoman for the Association told us: " This is a great opportunity to hear what the experts have to say and to debate with a wide iety of businesses so we can all make positive decisions in preparation for the unknown."We are particularly keen to hear from businesses in manufacturing, tourism, agriculture and food."On the  will be regional managing director of Mainetti, Jim Hutchison along with entrepreneur and business coach, Phil Morris, as well as a number of other key personalities from the Borders.Thursdays meeting starts at .pm.

title: javid-not-sad-his-father-would-be-turned-away-by-immigration-rule-changes

title: sturgeon-needs-more-clarity-before-sharing-second-referendum-thoughts
story: Nicola Sturgeon has said she may have to wait until November or even December to give an update on her plans for a second Scottish independence referendum.The Scottish First Minister said the lack of detail surrounding the UKrsquos departure from the European Union meant she was unable to make a judgment on whether to call for another independence vote.She insisted this was the case despite fears that Britain could be heading for a ldquogenuinely disastrous Brexit outcome ndash and even warned that Theresa Mayrsquos almost ldquodysal government could lead to a snap general election.The SNP leader said: ldquoIt may be this government is not far away from being unable to govern, I say that in seriousness.She noted the ldquocircus that is unfolding at the Tory party conference in Brimingham, where there has been speculation that the Prime Minister could face a leadership challenge.Nicola Sturgeon described the Conservative conference as a lsquocircusrsquo Ms Sturgeon added: ldquoWe are talking about a party in government that is not far away, I think, from being dysal, in terms of being able to govern at all.ldquoI certainly donrsquot think we should rule out the fact that there might be a general election.However she was clear that more detail is still needed on the UKrsquos future relationship with the EU before she can decide on whether to press for another vote on Scottish independence.Ms Sturgeon had previously indicated her willingness to fight a second referendum following the Brexit result in ,when Scotland voted to remain part of the EU but the UK as a whole opted to leave.However she pulled back from that position after the SNP lost a number of Westminster seats in the  general election ndash at the time pledging to set out her thinking on the issue in October.Speaking at the th anniversary of the Europa Institute at Edinburgh University, the First Minister said that while Scotland ldquomust retain the option to choose a dferent the ldquodecisive moments of the negotiations were now approaching, adding that the Scottish Government would publish a further document ahead of the key EU Council meeting in October ldquosetting out the case for compromise and common sense.Ms Sturgeon stressed her administration would continue to make the case for the UK to remain in both the single market and the customs union ndash even though this has been repeatedly ruled out by Westminster.The First Minister was asked directly by a member of the audienceshe would call for a second independence votethe UK ldquocrashes out with no deal.But she responded that she would set out her thinking when there is sufficient informationon the UKrsquos future relationship with the EU.The First Minister said that she would ldquowait until we are at title: letter the value of eu citizens
story: At the same time as the recent report from the Migration Advisory Committee outlined the impact of immigration on the UK, Oxford Economics published an assessment that highlighted the value of EU citizens to the British economy.It noted that when it comes to the public finances, European migrants contribute substantially more than they cost, easing the tax burden on other taxpayers.Taxes will therefore have to riseBrexit brings strict curbs on EU workers, because they pay far more to the public purse than British-born residents and also those from outwith the EU.Migrants from the EU contribute £, more to the exchequer each year in net terms than the average adult.Over their letimes, they pay in £, more than they take out in public services and benefits # while the average UK citizen’s net letime contribution is zero.Non-European migrants will make a positive net contribution of £, to £,This is because most EU migrants arrive fully educated, and many leave before the costs of retirement start to weigh on the public finances.In total, the net benefit from the class of  was expected to be £.bn, with £.bn coming from EU migrants and the remaining £.bn from migrants from the rest of the world.It is all well and good wanting to curb immigration from the EU, but people living in the UK must be made aware of the clear impact this will have on the British economy.Alex Orr,Flat , Leamington Terrace,Edinburgh.

title: popular-former-musselburgh-church-minister-is-remembered
story: The American-born clergyman served Musselburgh Congregational Church, on Links Street, for  years after being inducted as its minister in .A bachelor, he retired to Gford in .With the help of neighbours and friends he remained at home until April, when his growing frailty led to him being admitted to Midlothian Community Hospital.Just two weeks before he died, Mr Lindgren was moved to Herdmanflat Hospital in Haddington until a permanent home could be found but he passed away on July .Mr Lindgren was born in Lynn, Massachusetts, on May ,  his father Raymond was Swedish and his mother Effie was a Macleod from the isle of Skye.Mr Lindgren was ordained into church ministry in  at the age of , holding a list of degrees including a Bachelor of Arts, Bachelor of Theology, Master of Theology and PhD.He was inducted into the Ministry of Genoa Congregational Church in Nebraska, where he served for six years.With practical experience under his belt, he went on to complete a post-graduate degree at New College Edinburgh before arriving in Musselburgh, where he took an avid interest in community le.The Rev Janice Andrews, minister at Musselburgh Congregational Church, said: ldquoHe was one of the longest-serving members of Musselburgh Rotary Club.ldquoWhen Musselburgh hosted the district conference he was charged with preaching to , delegates ndash an onerous task but members had complete confidence in his ability to speak to such a large audience, he was so very competent.ldquoFor over  years of his ministry he served as chaplain to the  Musselburgh Squadron RAF Air Cadets.ldquoHe had a keen interest in antiques and collected old postcards.ldquoHe used this collection to publish an illustrated history of the towns and villages of East Lothian and the city of Edinburgh, evidence of his sincere interest in this beautul and historic area of Scotland.She added: ldquoDonald handled the Gospel with truth and diligence. His sermons were always topical, he was knowledgeable, articulate and had the ability to keep his hearers engaged.ldquoHis ministry was inclusive. He made everyone welcome whether they came regularly or very occasionally, he was always encouraging and approachable.ldquoHe procured a beautul organ built by George Holdrich in the late s for a church in Appleby in the Lake District which was due to be scrapped.ldquoDonald had it restored and installed in Musselburgh Congregational Church, where it continues to rouse worshippers today.Mr Lindgrenrsquos funeral at Musselburgh Congregational Church and Seafield Crematorium was well attended by the community of Musselburgh and Fisherrow.Representatives from many organisations he was associated with, including Musselburgh Rotary Club, Musselburgh Air Cadets and Fisherrow Yacht Club, were present to pay their last respects.

title: plea-for-volunteers-to-join-the-team-at-musselburgh-cab
story: Claire Grehan, volunteer support officer, said sometimes there could be three or four volunteer advisers on duty but the busy High Street office was down to just one that day. The restricted service was only for general advice, which makes up about a quarter of the total bureau work, but paid staff were still available for case work and outreach services as normal.Claire said: ldquoI think a lot of people donrsquot know that CAB is a volunteer-based charity, so we do rely on volunteers to be on reception, to become general advisers and also some of them do administrative work as well.She said that volunteers were often people who were retired but wanted to keep mentally active, those who were between jobs and wanted to build new skills, and law students looking for experience.Claire, who also handles financial capability issues at the CAB, started out as a volunteer adviser.She said: ldquoWe always need volunteers, who are the leblood of the CAB.ldquoWe have about  [volunteers] at the moment and  members of staff.ldquoWe put a lot into advisers and helping them but not everyone makes it at the other end.ldquoAs volunteers they can also take holidays whenever they want or attend appointments but it is important that we get a certain level of commitment.She added: ldquoGeneral advisers deal with everything from the dog next door barking too loudly to entitlement to benefits.ldquoThey also deal with dismissal cases, as well as helping people to make phone calls and write letters.ldquoAround  per cent of the cases will be about benefits and about  per cent on debt followed by employment, housing, customer and local issues.The CABrsquos other volunteer support officer, Magdalena Szulc, who also began as a volunteer, agreed with her colleague.She said: ldquoWe need people who can commit for six to seven hoursrsquo volunteering each week and the training programme, which can take six to eight months.ldquoThey also need good listening skills, to work well in teams, be open-minded, donrsquot judge people or their circumstances and enjoy helping people.She interviews the recruits, who, after initial training, get to lsquoshadowrsquo a general adviser before going it alone with support from the session supervisor.Musselburgh resident Andrew Aitken decided to become a volunteer adviser a year and a half ago as, even although he works, he found he had some free time on his hands.He said: ldquoIt is interesting and is goodyou can be of some use to people.ldquoIrsquom at the CAB for half a day twice a week.The next adviser training programme starts on Thursday, October .Anyone interested in getting involved should pick up an application form from the CAB, which is located on High Street.Alternatively, email info@musselburghcab.casonline.org.uk, phone    or go to the Musselburgh CABrsquos website musselburghcab.org.uk

title: racecourse-licence-is-extended-to-years-end
story: A further extension to its racing licence has been granted by the British Horseracing Authority .The licence had been due to expire at the end of the flat season next month but it will now continue beyond the four jump fixtures planned for November and December.The decision comes as East Lothian Council continues to look to appoint a third party to run the facility on its behalf.The coursersquos future had been in doubt following a breakdown in relations between the council and Musselburghrsquos racing representatives.Councillor Fiona OrsquoDonnell, chairwoman of Musselburgh Racecourse Associated Committee , said: ldquoThis further extension of Musselburgh Racecoursersquos licence reflects the very positive work which has taken place to secure the trackrsquos future.Four jump racing fixtures are planned between November  and December , with racing also taking place on New Yearrsquos Day.The BHA board has extended the licence to cover the  events and is conditional on a licence application being lodged with the national body, which is under way, and also keeping it updated on the progress of the procurement process to appoint a new operator.Musselburgh Racecourse will apply for a racecourse licence for  later this year.Members of MRAC are aware the BHA may issue further temporary licences throughout  while the process of appointing a third party to operate the racecourse is under way.Ms OrsquoDonnell added: ldquoThe procurement process for appointing a third party operator is being progressed and I look forward to reporting further progress in due course.

title: farewell-to-fizz-as-preston-lodge-high-school-ditches-drinks
story: The new initiative will begin from October  and follows a successful trial month earlier this year, lsquoFizz-Free Februaryrsquo, when pupils were encouraged to only drink water in school.Head Girl Anna Scott, , said that the move would have health benefits for pupils and increase concentration levels in classes.ldquoGet ready for a year of heightened focus and a stable, consistent level of energy throughout the day, along with improved learning ability, she said.ldquoWe are removing juice from our school and we need everyone to join in!She also explained that there would be an added incentive for pupils to throw away their sugary drinks.ldquoThis time around we have decided to add a new reward system into the mix, along with an opportunity to support the house competition, she added.ldquoDuring the first month we will be rewarding house points in registration to those who have brought water to school with them and extra points for those who do so with reusable bottles.ldquoThe S events committee will be running a competition to see who can design the best poster for when the school goes fizz-free on October .ldquoThere will be a prize for the winner and their creation will be posted around the school to advertise the event.Posters should be handed in to Mrs Nicoll by next Thursdayand must feature the phrase lsquoJoin the Cleansersquo.They can be either emailedor presented in a hard copy, and must also convey a positive attitude towards the goal of a water-only school.

title: rebecca-is-my-driving-force-says-mum-of-inspirational-teen-after-taking-on-great-north-run
story: Pam Dalgleish was among thousands taking part in the Great North Run in Newcastle and Tyneside.Pam, of Kingston, was raising funds for the Teenage Cancer Trust, which provided support to daughter Rebecca, who passed away in December .The -year-old had been diagnosed with a malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumourand inspired people from across the county and beyond with her positive attitude.Among Rebeccarsquos achievements was raising more than pound, for Childrenrsquos Hospices Across Scotland .Pam completed the Great North Run last year and was again on the starting line on September .She told the Courier each time she took part in an event it was emotional. She said: ldquoRebecca is the driving force behind everything I do.ldquoI feel a great strength she has given me to carry on just by the way she was. I feel I have gained her strength and positivity to do this stuff.About seven young people aged between  and  are diagnosed with a form of cancer every day in the UK.Pam, , said: ldquoI was just wanting to support the good causes that supported Rebecca when she was ill.Pam completed the course in just over three hours and six minutes, raising more than pound for the charity, and has not ruled out further fundraising challenges.Rebeccarsquos lsquobucket listrsquo included a bungee jump and a skye, something her mum fully intends to do in her daughterrsquos memory.Meanwhile, she is planning to swap her running shoes for her walking boots next year with another fundraiser in aid of CHAS.Pam will be heading to Morocco for a trek in the Sahara in November next year.More than  people attended former North Berwick High School pupil Rebeccarsquos funeral three years ago.Pam added: ldquoIt will be three years at the end of this year, which is frightening.ldquoIn some ways it seems to have gone by in a flash and in other ways it does not.To support Pam, go to just giving fundraising pam-dalgleish

title: sad-passing-of-leading-conservation-volunteer-margaret-wight-89
story: A diminutive figure with a great sense of humour, Margaret won the East Lothian Volunteer of the Year award in  for her work in particular with SOS Puffin, run by the Scottish Seabird Centre, and Aberlady Bay Local Nature Reserve.Between  and , Margaret went out on almost  work parties with SOS Puffin to the islands of Craigleith and Fidra, to clear vegetation from puffin burrows.She was also a volunteer at Aberlady Bay and, where, was a path warden and bumblebee monitor.Born in Aberlady in , Margaret grew up in ious East Lothian villages and was the eldest of seven children.She left school at  and worked on a farm later she joined the WRNS, serving as a cook before she married and settled in North Berwick with husband William Wight and children Rodger and Fiona.She worked for Crawfordrsquos the bakers for  years, including managing their North Berwick shop and for the last  years she lived in Macmerry.On retirement, Margaret filled her le with voluntary activities ndash as well as her conservation work, she was a fundraiser for the Childrenrsquos Hospice Association Scotland , Poppyscotland and Children Living With Metabolic Diseases .She joined charity expeditions to Everest Base Camp and Zimbabwe, and undertook two solo long-distance charity cycle rides in Scotland.John Hunt, organiser of SOS Puffin, said: ldquoMargaret was a wonderful supporter of SOS Puffin, coming out to the islands well into her s. At the end of a long work party, she would still be going strong while young ones were flagging.ldquoShe made many friends on these trips and left lots of happy memories.John Harrison, warden of Aberlady Bay Local Nature Reserve, added: ldquoMargaret was a truly inspirational person.ldquoMore often than not the first to get going on a task and the last to finish, Margaret would commonly work longer than volunteers a fraction of her age.ldquoShe was a very well-liked and fun member of the volunteer group, who achieved a great deal for nature conservation over the ten years she volunteered with us.Margaret passed away at the Edington Hospital, North Berwick, on September  she is survived by her children Rodger and Fiona, and her grandchildren Moyra and Andrew.

title: farewell-to-long-serving-choristers-at-st-marys-parish-church
story: The youngsters left Knox Academy this summer, with plans to head to university, college, work or to travel.A spokesman for St Maryrsquos Parish Church said: ldquoKara Singh, Phoebe Hayman, Robin Bellamy, Emma Wylie and Ailsa Wrinn have all sung with us since they were about eight or nine years old right up until S.ldquoTheir talent, support and dedication has been greatly appreciated and has been an inspiration to many of the younger choristers.ldquoWe wish them all well in their future studies and travels in le.Each of the teenagers was presented with a copy of Handelrsquos Messiah on Sunday, September .Meanwhile, the church has also said goodbye to Cole Bendall, the director of choirs, who has stood down for health reasons.The spokesman added: ldquoCole was only with us a short time but what an amazing time, with everyone benefiting from his marvellous musical talent. We will miss him and wish him all the very best for the future.Anyone who is interested in further information about the choristers and choir at St Maryrsquos can email choristers@stmaryskirkMeanwhile, a specially-composed piece of music rung out at the church as part of the Haddington  celebrations on August .A peal of , changes, which was specially composed for a new bell-ringing method named Haddington  Surprise Major, was rung by members of the Scottish Association of Change Ringers.The peal band included two members from the St Maryrsquos band of ringers.Taking three hours and  minutes to complete, the peal provided a backdrop of celebratory sound to the events of the day.

title: boost-for-bid-to-create-community-co-working-space-on-dunbar-high-street
story: Sustaining Dunbar revealed proposals in May to buy the former housing office on Dunbar High Street from East Lothian Council.It hopes to transform the building, which has lain empty for six years, into a workspace offering ldquoinspiration and support to freelancers, commuters, remote workers, artists, businesses, social enterprises and community groups in and around the town.The plan is a step closer after being awarded pound, from the Scottish Land Fund.Sustaining Dunbar claims the project could add pound, a year to the local economy.Osbert Lancaster, development officer, told the Courier: ldquoThe building has been standing empty for some time.ldquoUntil we know the full condition of the building and cost of remedial work and refurbishment, we donrsquot knowthe project will be financially viable. This grant will let us engage an architect to assess the building and estimate the costs.Sustaining Dunbar, formed in , is a community development trust and charity. It aims to bring people together to create practical projects across the Dunbar and East Linton area that improve quality of le, support the local economy, and enhance the natural environment.Mr Lancaster added: ldquoIf we can make it happen, it should be a win-win all round.ldquoNot only will it be great for the people using the co-working centre, it will bring more people and more trade to High Street and boost the local economy.ldquoA study we commissioned suggests it will add between pound, and pound, to the area each year. And profits from the operation will be invested in practical support for local community groups and social enterprises.Jo McNamara, chairwoman of Sustaining Dunbar, felt the funding boost was ldquoa signicant step towards our vision of developing something really special in Dunbar.She added: ldquoWhile creating more workspace is essential for the area, whatrsquos truly exciting is the way co-working spaces like this can bring people together ndash to share ideas, to collaborate and to build a stronger community.For more information, go to coworkingdunbar

title: community-rallies-round-to-send-gymnast-hamish-colgan-to-portugal
story: Hamish Colgan, , is a gymnast and has been selected to represent the UK in the upcoming TeamGym European Championships, held in Lisbon, Portugal, next month.Currently the TeamGym squad are not funded by GB Gymnastics and, as a result, athletes need to pay their own way regarding training, travelling, food and kit.But in just  hours and after just one Facebook post, the pound, target was smashed ndash but that came as no great shock to dad Hamish Snr.ldquoI wasnrsquot surprised, no, he told the Courier.ldquoI know what people round here are like with charity, particularly in Tranent ndash theyrsquore incredible.ldquoMaybe because itrsquos something positive for a change and people like happy stories. Itrsquos all for a good cause anyway.The appeal was initially posted on crowdfunding site JustGiving on August  by September , the amount of money raised stood at pound,.A fundraiser was arranged for next Saturdayin Macmerry Miners Welfare Club and Hamish said it would still go ahead.Starting at pm, the evening includes a disco, a raffle and a buffet, with tickets pound.Hamish revealed his sonrsquos massive commitment to the sport, packing it into a hectic schedule and giving it everything.ldquoHersquos really busy just now, because hersquos a student and hersquos training to be a nurse, so hersquos got a packed schedule, he said.ldquoHersquos got two jobs right now. He works in McDonaldrsquos and he works in a nursing home as part of his placement.ldquoHersquos had to go to every training camp becauseyou donrsquot go to every one you donrsquot get picked, simple as that.ldquoTheyrsquore usually down in England the last half-dozen have all been in London. ldquoDue to the cost of travel, Hamish revealed there could be mixed emotions after a team selection.ldquoIt is bittersweet, he said. ldquoI think there probably are some folk who just canrsquot afford it.ldquoSometimes Hamish leaves himself skint just going to the training camps. Butyou want to do it, you need to be able to pay.ldquoItrsquos a hard one. You could easily just chuck the towel in. But Hamish has gone this far, he couldnrsquot throw it away now.Another five athletes from East Lothian have been selected to go to the Championships, held in Oelas on October -.Adam Souter, Dylan Campbell , Sara Grfin , Carly McFaddenand Fraser McLeodall train at Musselburgh club Saltire Team Gymnastics and were selected after a British competition in April.

title: air-ambulance-called-to-primary-school
story: Police and the fire service were also called out to the school at about .am following reports that a female pupil had injured her leg.The air ambulance landed in the field behind the school but was not required and quickly took off again.Police told the Courier that the female pupil suffered only a "very minor" injury.A spokeswoman for East Lothian Council said: ldquoOne of our pupils unfortunately got their foot stuck in a climbing frame at the school so the Fire Service were called and were able to free the pupil."In the meantime, an ambulance was also called as a precaution."As it was not required, the air ambulance which arrived was sent away."The pupil has since been taken to hospital to be checked over as a precaution.

title: runners-raise-250000-in-scottish-half-marathon-and-10k
story: In excess of pound, was raised for more than charities, led by the eventrsquos official charity Cancer Research UK, and its three established Scottish charities:Chest Heart  Stroke Scotland, Alzheimer Scotland and Edinburgh Childrenrsquos Hospital Charity.Race participants were treated to glorious sunshine as the half-marathon runnerspounded the streets fromMeadowmill towards Longniddry, then near to the entrance of Gosford House before making their way back along the coast road to the finish line atMusselburgh Racecourse.The k began at am, with Harry Burnardcrossing the finish line first in a time of :.He was followed in second by Michael Carrolland in third by James Taylor .Shona McIntoshwas the first lady home in a time of : with Freya Rossand Zoe Pflugcoming second and third respectively.In the am-start half-marathon - contested by , runners - Kevin Liddlewon with a time of ::.He was chased home by Paul Featherstonein second and Jason Kellyin third.After his win, Kevin said: "Today was great, the weather was better than anticipated. There were four of us together at the five mile mark and then I dropped back slightly up to the half way point. But I stuck to the pace and eventually caught them up again. I only really shook Paul [Featherstone] with one mile to go, so Im delighted to take the win today."Only two seconds split first and second in the womens field, with Kiera Gorepipping Chloe Coxto first place.Claire Thomsoncame third.

title: plaque-installed-to-mark-home-of-champion-golfer
story: Andrew and Audrey Inglis recently installed a plaque in memory of Willie Park seniorat their house on Ravensheugh Road ndash near Musselburgh Links, one of the oldest golf courses in the world, where the famous Wallyford golfer spent his last days.They found about the historical link from Ian Wood, former sub-postmaster at Levenhall, after he spotted information online about the four-time Open winner.Mr Wood said: ldquoIt made mention that he died at Levenhall.ldquoWhilst I knew a little bit about golf history and its strong links with Musselburgh during my  years, up until , as sub-postmaster there, this was the first mention Irsquod seen of the Willie Park connection to Levenhall as opposed to Musselburgh and the Old Course.ldquoI use the Scotlandrsquos People website run by the National Records of Scotland in my local and family history research so quite quickly found Williersquos death registration in  together with the Park family entry on the  Census: both at Laurel Bank, Levenhall.ldquoI knew the house owners as former customers so when I next saw them I mentioned what Irsquod discovered and expected them to know about it, particularly as Andrew, like me, is a keen golfer. However, this was news to him and his we Audrey so I passed them copies of what Irsquod found.Mr Inglis made contact with Historic Scotland which supported his request to have the plaque installed on the front of their house.And Mr Inglis, who has lived in the house  years, said: ldquoWe are quite proud to tell people about it. It is good to support Musselburghrsquos heritage and do everything you can to attract people to the town.ldquoI have been up to the loft to seethere are any of Willie Park seniorrsquos putters but there are none!In a twist of fate, Mr Woodrsquos daughter and son-in-law live on Park Drive, Wallyford, which was named after Willie Park senior, a four-time winner of The Open.Mr Wood said: ldquoI think the plaque is a fitting tribute to Willie Park senior.He suggested that it would be good to see some kind of golfing trail, with accompanying leaflet, produced for the Honest Toun.A successful golf exhibition, curated by the great-grandson of Willie Park senior, Mungo Park, was held at Musselburgh Museum in the summer. He was in the town again last week to give a talk on Musselburghrsquos importance in the history of the sport.He said: ldquoMusselburgh Museumrsquos exhibition has just restored some of the townrsquos proper reputation in golf history.ldquoI am grateful to the owners of Laurel Bank and to Historic Scotland for giving my great-grandfather a singular place in that history. There are many others in the town whose story is as rich, and I hope that Musselburghrsquos position as the th centuryrsquos lsquohome of golfrsquo will come to be more widely understood.

title: sisters-set-to-raise-four-figure-sum
story: Musselburgh resident Veronica Noone, , took part in the September  event along with her sister Trisha Francis, , from Manchester, in aid of the charity Crohnrsquos  Colitis UK after family members were diagnosed with the conditions.They joined about , runners for the .-mile half marathon which stretched from Newcastle-upon-Tyne to South Shields.The siblings, who are originally from Tyneside, crossed the finishing line in two hours  minutes.Sir Mo Farah sealed a record-breaking fth victory by winning the elite menrsquos race in  minutes and  seconds.Among the celebrities taking part were singer Olly Murs, news presenter Sophie Raworth and model Nell McAndrew.Veronica, who has lived in Musselburgh for  years, and also serves as vice-chairwoman of Fisherrow Harbour and Seafront Association, said: ldquoWe got on great and have so far raised pound, but there is still more coming in.Veronica has also raised pound by offering work colleagues at Scottish Enterprise the chance to repaint parts of a le-size cow model from Cow Parade Edinburgh in exchange for donations.Its paint had been washed off following the event in , but the now repainted brightly coloured cow stays on a balcony at Scottish Enterprisersquos Edinburgh office.A pound contribution was given to Veronicarsquos cause from the staff charity fund.Crohnrsquos disease and ulcerative colitis are the two main forms of inflammatory bowel disease, affecting more than , people in the UK.To donate, go to justgiving fundraising veronica-noone

title: update-emergency-services-called-out-to-astley-house-in-north-berwick
story: Four fire engines attended Astley House, on the towns Dirleton Avenue, shortly after pm this afternoon .Residents at the nursing home were not evacuated, but gathered in the conservatory while fire crews dealt with the smoke, which theCourierunderstands was in a cupboard in a communal area of the nursing home.No-one was hurt but some residents have been transferred to the nearby Fidra Nursing Home.Dirleton Avenueremains closed in both directions and traffic in the surrounding area is much heavier than normal.The first fire crew stood down a short time ago, and police hope to have the road back open soon.

title: folk-favourites-yard-of-ale-ready-for-two-good-causes
story: The trio will raise funds for the Hollies Day Centre for older people and Musselburgh born Tom Fairnie, a singer-songwriter, who is preparing to go the musical trip of a letime to the USA.Yard of Ale was originally formed in  when Ian Lawson, Alistair McDougald and Colin Mackenzie all found themselves in Musselburgh.Alistair and Colin had married local girls and Ian had taken up a post in youth and community education. He also later married a Musselburgh girl.All three had dabbled in folk music in the past and regularly went to the Golf Tavern in Millhill, Musselburgh, to hear local folk singers, the Amulree Trio, Chris Egan and his daughters, Lorraine and Karen.Alistair explained: "We each would sing a few songs inidually in the triorsquos break. One week John Gillan, the owner of the pub, askedwe could try and fill a night when the Amulrees were unavailable."We had a practice, everything just clicked and Yard Of Ale was born. We played every Friday and Saturday at the Golf for three years and took our name from the yard glass which hung on the wall. We were encouraged by local comedian, Billy Nimmo , to try our hand in the club cabaret scene."Yard Of Ale then had many successful years on the pub and club circuit, winning the TV Times Pub Entertainers of the Year award. The band did well on ITVs New Faces and appeared on many television and radio shows including STVrsquos Thingummyjig and BBC Radio Scotlandrsquos Scottish Radio Orchestra Roadshow. During this time they also supported, amongst others, Matt McGinn, Hamish Imlach and Billy Connolly, and enjoyed an extended run in the Edinburgh Festival with the legendary Tim Hardin.They then went their separate ways with Alistair involved in solo cabaret work, Colin playing with the North Sea Gas folk group and Iain, the original guitarist, leading a rock band.In  the group reformed for a charity show at the Brunton Theatre with good friends The Mimics, a successful Musselburgh comedy showband who had also broken up previously, to mark the passing of their mentor Billy Nimmo. The event was so successful that the band decided to give it another go.Since then its popularity has continued to grow and it has been in great demand for concerts, folk festivals, corporate s, pub, hotel and club gigs all over Scotland and when on tour in Denmark and in Ireland.Peter Gillan, nephew of the Golfrsquos John Gillan, then joined the band when Ian retired in . Having spent many years playing solo as a singer and guitarist on the folk and country scenes, his experience added yet another dimension to the band.Walter Mowat joined Yard Of Ale in  when Colin retired. Over the years he has played in a number of folk and bluegrass bands and also plays violin in the Really Terrible Orchestra.Ian and Colin still occasionally feature with the band as deputies or for larger concerts.Alistair and Ian each have two sons who were brought up and educated in Musselburgh.Alistairrsquos sons were both taught at the Burgh School by Susan Macintosh, Peterrsquos we.Peter started his working le at Bruntonrsquos Wiremill and still works for Brunton Aero products as it is now. He has also become a leading light in the Musselburgh Athletic FCrsquos  Club.Alistair was a director for  years of the now defunct Musselburgh Fair Day Association which ran the annual trotting at Musselburgh racecourse. He also ran a youth club for a number of years in Northesk Church and was chairman of the Musselburgh Domino League for a few years.In August,Yard of Ale played a fundraiser for Musselburgh Athletic Football Club to help them achieve their transition to senior football.The fundraising concert for the Hollies Day Centre has been organised by Musselburgh and Inveresk Community Council. The sell-out event will take place on Friday at Loretto Church Hall.The Get Tom To Austin Fundraising Concert is planned for Saturday, November , at the Fisherrow Centre in South Street, Musselburgh. Mr Fairnie, , hoping to head to Texas next spring after being offered the chance to record an album of his own songs with the Grammy award winning producer Merel Bregante. formerly of the Nitty Gritty Dirt Band.

title: walkers-take-big-fit-walk-in-their-stride
