Ireland AwardsBusiness AwardsSports AwardsProperty AwardsPrint SupplementSearchGoHome# News# Northern IrelandA long drive home for Armagh familys  FordRebuilt car in ,-mile from Armagh to CortinaThe family with their restored  Mark I Ford CortinaBy Mark BainOctober   CommentsA long drive home for Armagh familys  FordBelfastAn Armagh family have completed a four-year labour of love by driving their restored  Ford Cortina through Europe to the town in Italy the car was named after and back again.https:www.belfasttelegraph news northern-ireland a-long-drive-home-for-armagh-familys--ford-.htmlhttps:www.belfasttelegraph news northern-ireland article.ece bf AUTOCROP h --_new__I.JPGEmailAn Armagh family have completed a four-year labour of love by driving their restored  Ford Cortina through Europe to the town in Italy the car was named after and back again..pushWhen Mandy Leyburns father Robert arrived home with the shell of the old Mark I Cortina in  she joked it would be lovely to drive it "home" some time in the future, not expecting to be taken literally.Mandysaid shes amazed at the reaction her -year-old car got during its trip through  European countries over two summer weeks to arrive in the Italian town of Cortina - and even more amazed that the car survived. "It really was just a shell when my dad brought it home. Hes always tinkered and restored cars and I wanted to help him. I guess this was my apprenticeship," said the -year-old nurse from Middletown.Mandy and her dad spent weekend after weekend lovingly restoring the car over the past four years."We just started it as a weekend project. We both work full-time, so it was a hobby for both of us," she said."My dad has always tinkered with cars but we took on quite a lot with this one. However, looking at it now, theres no way Id ever part with it. It has a lot of sentimental value."The Cortina caused quite a stir as Mandy, husband Justin Gormley, Robert and mum Jessica made their way through the Continent on the ,-mile road trip. The family spent a lot of their spare time posing for photographs. The Cortina was even commandeered for a photoshoot by a model agency in Paris."The whole experience made us feel pretty cool," added Mandy."Once the Cortina got through the MoT in June we decided wed go for it. We turned it into our family holiday, though we had to load the boot up with a lot of spare parts just in case, as we werent really sureour work on the car would last the pace."We thought about driving straight to Cortina and back again, but it was too good an opportunity to waste, so we planned the trip to take in a lot of the sights all of us wanted to see around Europe. It all went so well and we might plan another one."Apart from the UK, the car passed through the Republic, France, Belgium, Netherlands, Luxembourg, Germany, Switzerland, Liechtenstein, Italy, Austria, Slovenia and Monaco."Weve been through the Black Forest, driven across the Millau Viaduct in southern France, the highest bridge in the world, and around the famous Stelvio Pass in the north of Italy with its  hairpin bends," said Mandy."When we arrived in Cortina DAmpezzo in Italy the locals were amazed to see the car. "There are not that many of them still around, and even fewer managed to make it back to the town they were named after."Back in  a new Ford Cortina would have completed around  miles to the gallon, but Mandy said she wanted to make the car as economical as possible."You could say I had a trip like this in the back of my mind when we put a diesel engine in it, and in the end we were getting up to mpg, so that was well worth it considering how far weve managed to travel in it."

Pic Michael SmythBy Jonathan BellOctober   CommentsBelfast International Airport apology after chaotic delays at security checksBelfastBelfast International Airport has apologised to passengers after long delays were reported during security checks on Monday morning.https:www.belfasttelegraph news northern-ireland belfast-international-airport-apology-after-chaotic-delays-at-security-checks-.htmlhttps:www.belfasttelegraph incoming article.ece cb AUTOCROP h Airport_queues_.jpgEmailBelfast International Airport has apologised to passengers after long delays were reported during security checks on Monday morning..pushSocial media users reported "chaotic" scenes as they waited to get bags searched before heading into the departure lounge.Many took to Twitter to show long queues stretching down through the airport as they vented their frustration at the wait.Some labelled it as a "shambles" while others described the scenes as "chaotic". One user joked it would soon be quicker to drive to Dublin than get through the airports security.Its thought bottlenecks occur because of people arriving at the airport too early for their flight while others show up at the advised time leading to more passengers than expected arriving at one time. The airport took to the social network to remind people to arrive at least two hours before departure."Carefully packing your bags at home can help us reduce the time it takes to get you through security," it tweeted.A spokeswoman added: "We apologise to any passengers who suffered delays as a result of queues at security this morning. Customer services staff were on hand to deal with any passenger queries and  indeed any passengers with feedback or complaints we would ask them to contact the airport directly so that we may resolve their issues."Dont forget to arrive at least  hours before your flight and that carefully packing your bags at home can help us reduce the time it takes to get you through security. Check out hand luggage guidance: https:t.co VwFXCnIJ pic LLtTyDrM— Belfast AirportOctober , "The security search area was fully staffed with all security lanes open for the number of departing flights this morning. We again urge passengers to arrive at the airport at least two hours before their flight is due to depart, evenyou are travelling with hand luggage only, and to be prepared for the security search."Long queues at security were reported over the summer causing much frustration. And last Monday the airport blamed equipment failure for long delays though its security.Michael Smyth - a union official for Nautlilus International which represents ferry workers - arrived early at the airport for his flight to Liverpool for his organisations annual conference.He is a regular flyer visiting many of the UKs ious ports. He said he queued for an hour on Monday and while he made his flight with time to spare he said others turned back in the queue saying they had missed theirs."The queue was all the way down the escalator," he said."I just couldnt understand it as all the lines were open and they were processing everyone at a fair rate. It was not like it was going slow, it was just the sheer volume of people trying to get through."And by the time I got through it all the queue was just the same . It was a nightmare."He added: "We went away for our holidays in the summer and had a  minute queue then. But you expect that over the Twelfth fortnight not at the beginning of October when it is mainly just commuters."The thing that really got me today was there was no one giving advice or even helping people who were about to miss their flights. There were some asking to get past to catch a flight and people were letting them through, but there needed to be better assistance.""Had I missed my flight I would have missed important meetings today."The airport pledged to end long delays after it announced a new company would be taking over the handling of security. Wilson James will take over security operations on November .Belfast International Airport urged passengers to be prepared for security checks before arriving at the airport to speed the process along."Adhering to these guidelines and carrying only essential items in hand luggage can help reduce the need for manual checks at security, which can quickly cause queues to build up," the spokeswoman added.The airports guidelines include: Ensuring hand luggage is not densely packedAll non-essential liquids are packed in hold baggageAny liquids brought through security must be in a l resealable plastic bag All laptops, tablets etc must be removed from  hand luggage Remove all coats, belts etc

Ireland AwardsBusiness AwardsSports AwardsProperty AwardsPrint SupplementSearchGoHome# News# Northern IrelandPregnant sheep skinned in Northern Ireland field - legs choppedDisgust: Arron LamontBy Victoria LeonardOctober   CommentsPregnant sheep skinned in Northern Ireland field - legs choppedBelfastA farmer has expressed his shock after finding one of his heavily pregnant sheep skinned, with all four of its legs chopped off and its throat slit.https:www.belfasttelegraph news northern-ireland pregnant-sheep-skinned-in-northern-ireland-field-legs-chopped-.htmlhttps:www.belfasttelegraph news northern-ireland article.ece bf AUTOCROP h --_new__I.JPGEmailA farmer has expressed his shock after finding one of his heavily pregnant sheep skinned, with all four of its legs chopped off and its throat slit..pushPart-time farmer Arron Lamont made the grisly discovery in his field between Kilrea and Rasharkin early yesterday morning.He has reported the matter to the PSNI but said he wanted to warn other farmers of what had happened.Arron said he initially thought a dog was responsible for killing the pedigree Dorset ewe.But he said there is no way an animal could have carried out such an attack."It was like a butcher job," he said.He added that wire fencing had been damaged and the gate into the pen was open.He thinks the attacker pulled the ewe down the field where they cut its throat with a kne. Arron said that the hedge sits lower than the road, so they couldnt be seen.He believes it is there that the pregnant animal was hung up on barbed wire to be skinned and had its legs cut off in the barbaric attack."You can see the clean lines of the kne, and the wool and the skin was cut off - not pulled off," he said last night.Arron explained he had been trying to build up his flock, but now another of his sheep has lambed early because of what he believes is trauma.The lorry driver said he was keeping the horric story from his two young children - a son and daughter aged seven and six respectively - as it was too disturbing.He described those behind the grim attack as "total scum to do this to an innocent animal", which he believed would have suffered."How anyone could do this to an animal is beyond me," he said. "Someone knew what they were doing."This wasnt a five minute job."It wasnt a pretty sight to come across this morning," he added.

republic-of-ireland good-friday-agreement-not-up-for-negotiation-leo-adkar-.htmlhttps:www.belfasttelegraph incoming article.ece cf AUTOCROP h bpanews_e-d-e-ac-be_EmailThe Good Friday Agreement is not up for negotiation, Ireland’s premier has said, after DUP leader Arlene Foster claimed the peace deal was not sacrosanct..pushTaoiseach Leo Varadkar said the  accord between the UK and Irish Governments cannot be changed by one political party or one government.His comments come after Mrs Foster suggested the terms of the agreement could be altered in efforts to strike an EU exit deal.Mr Varadkar, however, said the Good Friday Agreementwas not up for negotiation in the Brexit talks.It is not a piece of British legislation, it is an international agreement between the British and Irish governments, as well as a multi-party agreement among the ious partiesLeo VaradkarFacebookTwitterSpeaking in the Irish parliament on Tuesday, the Fine Gael leader said: “The government stands by the GFA and we will defend its primacy.“We see our role as the Irish government as the co-defenders of that agreement.“It is not a piece of British legislation, it is an international agreement between the British and Irish governments, as well as a multi-party agreement among the ious parties.“While it may be factually correct to say that the Good Friday Agreement, just like any international treaty, could be changed, it can only be changed with the agreement of British and Irish governments and can only be changed with the consent of the people of Northern Ireland and indeed across cross-community consent.“It is not something that can be changed by any one political party or by any one government.“It is certainly, as far as this government is concerned, the Good Friday Agreement is not up for negotiation in these talks over Brexit.”Critics of Brexit on the island of Ireland have warned of its potential to undermine aspects of the international treaty, including its provisions for cross-border co-operation and rights protections.The DUP campaigned against the Good Friday Agreement when it was resoundingly endorsed in referenda on both sides of the border in .Elements of the deal have been altered by subsequent political agreements in Northern Ireland, such as the  St Andrews Agreement.It has been deeply frustrating to hear people who voted Remain and in Europe talk about Northern Ireland as though we can’t touch the Belfast AgreementArlene FosterFacebookTwitterIn an interview with the Daily , Mrs Foster said: “It has been deeply frustrating to hear people who voted Remain and in Europe talk about Northern Ireland as though we can’t touch the Belfast Agreement. Things evolve, even in the EU context.“There has been a lot of misinterpretation, holding it up as a sacrosanct piece of legislation.”Mr Varadkar’s comments come after Sinn Fein president Mary Lou McDonald accused the DUP leader of using “dangerous and reprehensible” comments about the GFA.Speaking in the Dail, she said: “They reveal a reckless disregard for the peace process, for prosperity and for progress.”Brexit is incompatible with the Good Friday Agreement. The actions of the DUP and their deal with the Tories is bad for our economy and undermines the rights of citizensMary Lou McDonaldFacebookTwitterThe latest row between the DUP and Sinn Fein comes amid the ongoing political impasse in Northern Ireland following the collapse of the powersharing institutions in early .“The Good Friday Agreement was endorsed by the vast majority of people north and south,” said the Sinn Fein president.“It is the people’s agreement and not a chip to be bargained with as part of any Tory DUP Brexit deal.“Brexit is incompatible with the Good Friday Agreement. The actions of the DUP and their deal with the Tories is bad for our economy and undermines the rights of citizens.“The DUP should commit to the full implementation of the Good Friday, and other agreements, rather than seeking to undermine them.“This would unlock the pathway to re-establishing the political institutions and safeguarding the interests of all the people in the north.”The Good Friday Agreementenshrines the “consent principle” that Northern Ireland’s position within the UK can only changea majority of the region’s citizens vote for it.Ulster Unionist Party leader Robin Swann claimed Mrs Foster’s comments potentially undermined that principle.“Arlene Foster’s comments on the Belfast Agreement are strategically shortsighted,” he said.“The DUP may have been happy to corrupt the  agreement for their own ends at St Andrews, but I cannot believe the DUP leader has been so careless as to throw it open in such a haphazard way which is of no benefit to unionism.“The reality is that the principle of consent is what binds us to the United Kingdom, it is the best settlement for unionists and should be sacrosanct.”Ireland’s deputy premier Simon Coveney called Mrs Foster’s comments “wrong”.He tweeted: “I have respect for Arlene, but she is wrong on this. He could be seen banging on windows of the terminal trying to get the aircraft to wait.He then broke through a door and made his way onto the apron, trying to flag the aircraft down.The man was seen by passengers already on board the flight making the charge across the tarmac toward the plane before staff intervened.Gardai were called to the scene at around am.The man, who is in his s, has been arrested and taken to Ballymun Garda Station where he is currently being detained.A spokesperson for Dublin Airport said the man, aged in his s, was handed over to gardai and taken to the Ballymun station.A Ryanair spokesman said the inidual breached security at the boarding gate, which had already closed."This is now a matter for local police," he added.

chuck Chequers DUP has ‘concerns’ over Chancellor’s no-deal Irish border plan Mr Dodds said any agreement had to be "crystal clear" and his party would not accept a fudge on any Brexit withdrawal agreement..The North Belfast MP was speaking at a Conservative party conference fringe event on Tuesday.He said: “The danger of this Irish backstop has the potential to not only separate Northern Ireland from the rest of the United Kingdom and any future ersion there may be from it, but it also has the potential to shackle the United Kingdom for generations to come in its relationship with Europe.“The DUP will not be signing up to any backstop unless we ensure that every line of it complies with our requirements.”He also took a pot shot at the Chancellor, revealing he had told the Government that Mr Hammond’s next Budget needed to “reflect optimism”, adding: “We have had enough doom and gloom.”DUP leader Arlene Foster, also speaking at the event, said her party was not "bluffing" on the issue and they would not allow the UK to be broken up by Brussels.Watch: Arlene Fosters reaction after Karen Bradley praise for BBC - what did she say DUPs Foster backs Boris Johnsons Brexit plan and says Good Friday Agreement not sacrosanct . ⁦@NigelDoddsDUP⁩ says any backstop must be time limited  cant tie NI into arrangements which don’t apply to the rest of the U.K. pic ypFhzOHYDw— Mark DevenportOctober , “I picked an Orange pen especially for you Mrs Foster” said the man with the broken arm pic QqBlvfD— EndaOctober , The comments come as it was reported Theresa May was sitting on "secret" plans for new working on the so-called backstop.The backstop is a contingency fall back should the EU and the UK not agree a deal. The EU has insisted this be agreed before talks can progress.Theresa May to reveal secret Brexit plan for Ireland border backstop Bloomberg reported on Monday Mrs May is set to make a signicant new Brexit offer that would kick-start negotiations in the coming weeks.The offer applies to the backstop, which is the legal guarantee that there will no hard border on the island of Ireland.The report said: "Under the plan, which May is likely to put forward later this month, the UK would back down on its opposition to new checks on goods moving between the British mainland and Northern Ireland."In exchange, Mays team would need the EU to compromise and allow the whole of the UK including Northern Ireland to stay in the blocs customs regime."However, sources in Dublin said they understood this to mean that Mrs May was moving towards delivering a new legal definition of the backstop.The version produced by the EU last February was ruled unworkable by the UK Government.

title: eamon melaugh host talk 50th anniversary civil rights movement museum free
story: As part of their new  Years of Revolution,  Years On programme, the award-winning Museum of Free Derry will host a talk by local civil rights veteran Eamon Melaugh this Wednesday, October , at pm.A packed programme of events was unveiled at last week’s launch event - a fascinating talk on the early movement by Michael McLoughlin, who was labelled Protestor # in government letters banning the north’s first civil rights march from Coalisland to Dungannon.On Wednesday the Museum of Free Derry continues its October November programme, marking half a century since some of the most important events of the civil rights campaign.googletag.cmd.push .addSize.addSize.buildslot  googletag.defineSlot.defineSizeMapping.setTargeting.setTargeting.setTargeting.addServicegoogletag.displaygoogletag.pubads.refreshFty years to the day he and others received letters banning the  October march, activist and photographer Eamon Melaugh, a founding member of both the Derry Housing Action Committeeand the Derry Unemployment Action Committee , will reflect on the civil rights movement,  years on.The event will be hosted by Irish News journalist Seamus McKinney and admission is free.You can visit www.museumoffreederry.org to find out about other upcoming events.

title: sdlp host civil rights discussion featuring labour mp went viral last week strong views effect brexit ireland
story: The SDLP will host a discussion this Saturday in the Museum of Free Derry on the fight for civil rights  years ago and the fight that continues today. The discussion will include Labour MP Stephen Pound as a list who will share his views on the fight for civil rights  years on from the Civil Rights Movement. Mr Pound, who is the Labour Shadow Minister for Northern Ireland, went viral last week after a video was made of him speaking in defence of the rights of citizens across Ireland from Brexit. Mr Pound is expected to speak on the challenge of Brexit and the impact on the rights of citizens across Northern Ireland, including the impact on the Irish border and the Peace Process.Commenting ahead of the event SDLP Leader Colum Eastwood said: “The Civil Rights Movement belongs to no one party - it belongs to the people. However, for us in the SDLP it has a special part in our history as our party was founded directly from the Civil Rights Movement. googletag.cmd.push .addSize.addSize.buildslot  googletag.defineSlot.defineSizeMapping.setTargeting.setTargeting.setTargeting.addServicegoogletag.displaygoogletag.pubads.refresh“ years on from when citizens marched together in the defence of equality and opportunity for all, it is right that we remember but also that we revive our sense of determination to deliver a future based on fairness for all peoples.“As we face into the uncertainty of Brexit, here in Derry we will have an open discussion with voices from the Civil Rights Movement then and also with those of us committed to delivering civil rights now. This event is open to all. "It is important that we come together to find solutions to the major threats that now face us. This is the time to renew our sense of purpose, our sense of community and deliver justice and opportunity for all.”The event, Civil Rights Then and Now from .pm to .pm, Saturday, October , in the Museum of Free Derry. Panellists to include Stephen Pound MP, Councillor Mairia Cahill and Former Deputy First Minister Mark Durkan among others.Pictured above: Stephen Pound on Channel  News - the clip went viral for his strong views on the impact of Brexit on the rights of citizens across Northern Ireland, including the effect on the Irish border and the Peace Process.

title: 1%2C400 people on housing waiting list
story: THE need for social housing across the district remains high with the problem particularly acute in Newcastle and Downpatrick, new figures have revealed.Local politicians were told this week that there are over , people on the waiting list for social homes district-wide, with , classed in the urgent need category.The figures revealed by the Housing Executive confirm that just over  people are seeking social homes in Newcastle, with  in the so-called urgent need category. In Downpatrick,  are on the waiting list, with  in urgent need.Last year, a total of  social homes were allocated in both towns, with the Executive confirming work is currently underway to build  new homes in Newcastle and  in Downpatrick as part of the first phase of the redevelopment of the former Downe Hospital site.The waiting list figures were outlined at Monday nightrsquos meeting of Newry, Mourne and Down Council, with politicians saying they are acutely aware of the pressure on housing officials to meet increasing need.They say they are willing to do all they can to help and hope land can be secured to build more social homes to help reduce waiting list numbers. Last year,  homes were allocated across the district.It was also confirmed on Monday night that  people are on the waiting list for social housing accommodation in Ballynahinch, with  in the urgent need category.In the Castlewellan and Drumaroad area,  people are seeking homes, with  in urgent need, while  people are on the list for social accommodation in Killyleagh. Just under half of the applicants are in the urgent need bracket.Elsewhere, the newly published figures reveal there are  people on the waiting list for homes in the Crossgar and Annacloy area, with  in urgent need.Sixty two people are on the waiting list for homes in Saintfield and Ardglass, which includes Ballyhornan and Dunsford, with the urgent need figures  and  respectively. There is no one on the waiting list for social homes in Kilmore.The total number of people on the waiting list for homes across the entire Newry, Mourne and Down Council area is ,, with , in urgent need. The total number of homes allocated the district during the last year was .A spokeswoman for the Executive said the organisation is committed to working with the local authority through the community planning and local development plan processes to identy opportunities to meet housing demand and encourage mixed tenure developments where social and affordable housing are brought forward, supporting the development of inclusive and cohesive communitiesldquoThe requirement for new social housing has remained at a very high level since  across the Newry Mourne and Down Council area, with the five year projection showing a requirement for , units, said the spokeswoman.She said need remains highest in Newry , Newcastle , Warrenpointand Downpatrick .ldquoThere is also an unmet need evident throughout the villages of Castlewellan, Bessbrook Derramore, Crossgar, Saintfield and Rostrevor. Single, older people and small family households comprise % of the waiting list and the predominance of single and small family households underlines a signicant requirement for one and two bedroom homes, said the spokeswoman.She said at the end of March this year, there were  social homes being constructed on site, including  in Newry,  in Newcastle and  in Downpatrick.The number of new homes under construction in Castlewellan and Crossgar are  and  respectively.The Executive spokeswoman added: ldquoThere are a further  social housing units programmed to start through the Social Housing Development Programme, with  social homes completed during  ..prettyPhoto

title: Ardglass coastal clean up
story: A SECTION of inaccessible and rocky coastline in Ardglass was last week cleaned by volunteers with the help of local canoeists.The clean-up mdash organised jointly by the Loch Cuain Canoe Club and the Strangford and Lecale Partnership mdash saw dozens of people show up to clean an area between the village and nearby Sheepland.Canoeists, led by local councillor Cadogan Enright, ferried the giant bags of rubbish out to waiting boats organised by the Rogers family from Portaferry who took them to Ardglass harbour.There, they were winched up and placed in a waiting skip provided by the villagersquos harbour master, with the weekend clean-up the second such initiative to remove rubbish from inaccessible areas at the Ulster Way along the Lecale coast.Loch Cuain Canoe Club members included Joe and Gareth Fitzsimons from Ardglass, as well as Cllr Enright and his son, Cad Oacuteg, who used the occasion to highlight upcoming training courses for families wanting to get involved in canoeing locally to be held in Castleward Bay and on the Quoile River this autumn.ldquoAny family interested in joining in wildle or other environmental projects by canoe in the Lecale Strangford area can contact us on Facebook, said the councillor.The weekend event attracted volunteers from the Ards peninsula as well as others from Ardglass who were joined by people from Killough, including Marty Rice and his family.There was also a contingent from Downpatrick and Robert Hillman and Fiona Robinson from Crossgar, with the Newcastle Wild Sea Swimmers spotted collecting rubbish on shore.Newry, Mourne and Down Council chairman Mark Murnin thanked the volunteers for their efforts and joined them for a well earned cuppa at the harbour.Cllr Enright thanked the Strangford Lough and Lecale Partnershiprsquos Judith Caldwell for organising the day and for helping organise several other clean-ups along the Lecale Coast this year.The coastal clean-up in Ardglass took place after  volunteers joined a beach clean at Tyrella the previous weekend as part of a province-wide initiative supported by volunteers and Coca-Cola employees.The Big Beach Clean initiative involved a number of beaches including Tyrella, with Jodie McAneaney, the lsquoLive Here Love Herersquo manager at Keep Northern Ireland Beautul, thanking all those who took part.She said: ldquoItrsquos important we educate people on protecting our marine le and our coastline itrsquos such a crucial part of our environment and also our heritage in Northern Ireland. Something we should be proud to take great care of..prettyPhoto

title: Ballygowan firm in major £35m project
story: A BALLYGOWAN engineering firm is the sole Northern Ireland business to be involved in a poundm research project to develop a new electric specialist vehicle for Jaguar Land Rover.Advanced composites manufacturer CCP Gransden, established in  with its roots in shipbuilding and employing  staff, is to be part of the lsquoProject Tucanarsquo consortium, which it says will future-proof the business and provide opportunities for signicant future growth.The firmrsquos managing director Jim Erskine, said it has developed an advanced composite manufacturing cell that is highly automated and enables it to manufacture composite parts at a fast rate and to a high quality.ldquoWersquore delighted Jaguar Land Rover has given us the opportunity to work with them on this important project, he continued. ldquoWe are proud to be at the forefront of continuing to develop the manufacturing sector within Northern Ireland.Electried vehicles require stfer, lighter vehicle structures to boost their performance.Project Tucana will deliver this vision by developing world-leading cost effective, scalable carbon fibre composite solutions. In doing so the project will allow the true environmental credentials of electric vehicles to be realised by enabling wider adoption.CCP Gransden is a member company of the Northern Ireland Advanced Composites and Engineering Centre .Its general manager Dave Thompson said to be associated with one of the most iconic names in motoring history is a ldquofantastic endorsement of the aim, focus and professionalism of CCP Gransden.He added: ldquoWe have seen the company consistently invest in their technical skills and capabilities over a number of years. Their innovation and expertise in the use of composite materials, particularly for high-end automotive use, marks the company out as one of the most innovative in this area. This latest endeavour will increase their capabilities even further.Dr Leslie Orr, regional director of ADS, the national trade body representing aerospace, defence, security and space sectors, also welcomed CCP Gransdenrsquos participation in the project.He added: ldquoAutomotive, aerospace, defence and other industries are looking for new materials and processes to make their products stronger and at the same time lighter.ldquoCCP Gransden are a progressive and innovative SME, developing new composites materials and new ways of making products. Driving forward on projects like this will keep them at the forefront of these new technologies and open new markets and opportunities..prettyPhoto

title: Call for greater use of community hall
story: THE Crossgar War Memorial Community Hall is a facility for the use of everyone in the village and surrounding areas.It is home to a number of organisations and weekly events with those who run the hall mdash it opened in November  mdash keen to expand its use to further cement its place in the heart of the community.An extension was added in  to enhance the existing hall which has undergone a major transformation itself with the interior revamped.A dedicated management team looks after the hall with three of its members keen to see more people coming through the door, making the most of what it can offer.Helen Graham, Robert McClurg and Jim Brownlees say the community hall is for everyone, describing the facility as well maintained and very capable of meeting a iety of needs, boasting two excellent kitchens.ldquoWe have plenty of activities at the moment, said Helen, ldquobut there is plenty of space for more. We are encouraging more users to come forward and make the most of what the hall and the annex has to offer.ldquoThe hall is well used from Monday to Thursday, but there are slots available for Friday and Saturday. We get funding from Newry, Mourne and Down Council to help us meet our costs and we also receive income from user groups to help meet overheads.The management committee is delighted with local authority support and hopes to meet shortly with the councilrsquos chief executive, Liam Hannaway, and the districtrsquos first citizen, Slieve Croob councillor Mark Murnin.Anyone wishing to make a donation to help meet the hallrsquos running costs is asked to come forward, with the management committee also securing grant aid as a result of Robertrsquos hard work.ldquoOur main goal is to encourage more people to use these excellent facilities, particularly young people, Helen explained.Currently, the hall hosts Slimming World sessions, Jujitsu classes, indoor bowls and a hugely successful gardening club. There is also sequence dancing and yoga classes.ldquoWe have two bowling sessions on a Wednesday. The afternoon session is for those who perhaps did bowl in the past and now want to throw the odd wood, but not take part in competitive games. The session runs between .pm and .pm andyou donrsquot want to bowl you can have a cup of tea and a chat. In the evening from .pm, the hall is used by Crossgar Bowling Club, Helen explained.ldquoWe have available slots for Friday and Saturday for a facility which is based in the heart of the community and we are very much keen to encourage greater community use. The annex can also be used for birthday parties as it is the ideal size and we have had a bouncy castle in their in the past.Keen to ignite fresh interest, there is a need to continue meeting overheads to pay bills with a fundraising iety concert taking place on Thursday, October  at .pm.The event features Ailish McBride, Kevin Kearney, Billy McFarland, Elaine and Nigel Black and Shaun Loughrey. The compere is Gary Wilson with music also provided by Country Harmony.Tickets, priced pound, available by contacting   . They can also be purchased at the door on the night.Robert said the hall committee also runs dances to help generate funds with a jumble sale and car boot sale in the offing, while Jim hopes more people will come forward to make use of the facility.The next major event after the fundraising concert is the hallrsquos annual meeting in November which the management committee is encouraging local people to attend..prettyPhoto

title: Decision time in semi finals
story: THERE are GAA championship semi-final showdowns all the way this weekend.The action gets underway on Friday night at Pairc Esler in Newry when Darragh Cross face Liatroim in the first of the Parador Lodge IFC semi-finals at .pm. This will be followed by the Morgan Fuels SFC last four encounter between derby rivals Burren and Mayobridge at .pm.Twenty-four hours later at the same venue, Bredagh and Saul lock horns in the IFC at .pm and at pm champions Kilcoo take on Warrenpoint in the SFC.The Darragh Cross v Liatroim clash is a tough one to call.Both teams play in Division  with Darragh enjoying the better of results and are sitting just outside the top four with games in hand. Inconsistency has plagued Liatroim all season and they are precariously perched fourth from bottom with three league games left to play.Darragh beat Liatroim in the league - to - back in August and also accounted for Atticall, Drumgath and Bredagh in the championship, while Liatroim lost to Atticall, but saw off Dundrum and St Johnrsquos in the Championship.Darragh will look to Matty Hardy, Oisin McConvey, Shane Murray, Lee Morrison, Marcus Miskelly and Michael Monan with Liatroim banking on big games from P J Davidson, Conor and Ruairi McCrickard, Gerard McAnulty and Liam Middleton.Darragh seem to have the edge in experience and their exciting attacking formation should be too much for Liatroim to handle.The Burren v Mayobridge SFC clash is expected to be an intriguing affair with no quarter asked or given.Paddy OrsquoRourkersquos side sit proudly at the top of the ACFL Division , but lost both league games this season to Mayobridge, who are six points behind the leaders with a game in hand.Burren have been impressive in beating Loughinisland, Carryduff and Castlewellan to get this far with Mayobridge accounting for An Riocht, Saval and Clonduff.Burren are a solid all-round side and can rely on Donal OrsquoHare, Liam Kerr, Paudie Poland, Ryan Treanor, Cathal Foy and David McEntee to take and make scores.Benny Coulter has Mayobridge purring again and in Ryan Brady, Cathal Magee, Caolan Gallagher, Conleth OrsquoHare and Kevin McClorey he has potential match winners who will all need stoppingBurren are to progress.Bredagh are expected to see off Saul in the IFC on Friday night, given they play in a higher ision.However, Saul are just one more win away from lting the Division  title and a win over Glasdrumman in their last game on October  will see them promoted as champions.On their day, Bredagh are a match for anyone and should have too much power for Saul. However, Donnan Ritchiersquos side showed against a fancied Ballymartin outfit that they fear one one andthey can repeat that sort of display then Bredagh may watch out.Bredagh will look for big efforts from Donal Hughes, Tommy McElroy, Donal McKegney, Michael Robinson, Conor Francis and Owen Costello with Saul relying on Adam King, Cathail Arnold, the Harney brothers, Caolan Magee and Rory Mullen.Unfortunately, star player Pierce Laverty will miss the game as he headed off to Australia on Sunday to take part in a week-long series of Aussie Rules trials.Following this game, Kilcoo will continue in their bid to make it seven-in-a-row when they face Warrenpoint.Kilcoo have again arrived at this stage of the competition with a minimum of fuss and itrsquos going to take an exceptional side to wrestle the Frank OrsquoHare Cup from their grasp.Ryan and Jerome Johnston look to be flying again after an injury-interrupted season and they have the perfect foils in Conor Laverty and Ceilum Doherty with Paul Devlin directing affairs in and around the middle of the park.The Branagan brothers are also expected to have a massive impact on the game as they set about taming Joe Magee, Aaron Magee, Ross McGarry, Ryan Mallon and Ryan and John Boyle.There is also a county final to look forward to on Sunday when Portaferry and Ballycran battle it out for the Senior Hurling Championship title in Ballygalget at pm..prettyPhoto

title: From the pages of the Down Recorder%2C September 26%2C 1978
story: BALLYNAHINCH mdash Plans for a new factory in Ballynahinch to manufacture cane furniture could bring  new jobs to the area.A new company mdash Pinewick Manufacturing mdash a subsidiary of the Pinewick shops, has applied for planning permission to build a , square feet factory on the Hillsborough Road.The ambitious venture has been planned by Mr Peter Wilkin, who has been running the Pinewick organisation for the past four years andproposals are approved then the new building would be able to provide  jobs within three years.Pinewick has shops in Ballynahinch, Belfast and Ballymoney and its Ballynahinch pilot production plant has been turning out a iety of goods, including plant stands, telephone tables and wall plant holders. These articles are presently being manufactured by a workforce of seven, butthe proposed scheme swings into action a whole new range of items can be produced.At the beginning of the year Mr Wilkin set about finding out just what local talent could produce and thus a new local industry was born in a small workshop behind the Ballynahinch shop.While Mr Billy Burrowes, one of the first employees of Pinewick and now a director, was trained as a joiner, the rest of the workers picked up the craft remarkably quickly. Mr Wilkin thinks the new project would be of great benefit to the community and would be unlikely to provide any training problems.CASTLEWELLAN mdash A dispute over transporting a young Castlewellan girl to school brought a stinging attack on Education Minister Lord Melchett this week. Castlewellan councillor Mrs Ethel Smyth has labelled the behaviour of Lord Melchett as ldquodisgraceful and called for immediate action.The furore centres around a five year-old girl whose father wants her to attend a state controlled school in Dundrum or Castlewellan. However, because she lives in the country outside Castlewellan she would need to have school minibus transport provided for her.According to Mrs Smyth, she has been told by the South Eastern Education and Library Board that the child will have to go to a maintained school in Annsborough which would exclude the need for transport arrangements.ldquoThe childrsquos father wants her to go to a controlled school and he is entitled to have her do so, Mrs Smyth said. ldquoI am thoroughly disgusted and I think that the Department of Education must be totally inefficientthey donrsquot answer within a month.DOWNPATRICK mdash There just seems to be no stopping the Downpatrick supergroup Rosetta Stone, who recently completed another dynamic tour of Japan and will be setting off on a trip to Thailand later this year.The five members of the group mdash Damien, Terry and Colin McKee, Andy LeGear and Ian Mitchell mdash are just back from their second conquering trip to Japan where their latest hit, Sheila, is currently number one.In the last year the band have been playing constantly across the globe and have built up a huge following in many countries, including Germany and Canada. But it has been in Japan that Rosetta Stone have really shot to stardom.This was one of the first countries which the band visited after its formation and it became clear from the start that the young Irish lads obviously had something which appealed to Japanese girls.At the end of their first Japanese tour each member of the group received a gold disc for mass sales of their LP, Rock Pictures, and their first two singles also thundering into the Japanese charts.Now they have gone and taken Japan by storm again where they are playing to crowds of between , and , twice a day.KILCLIEF mdash Strangford police have appealed to the public to help them trace keys which were stolen from a car on Saturday.The car, a Chrysler Hillman Minx, had been parked in a field at Kilclief between . and pm while Mr John McMullan, of Drumroe Road, was working. When he arrived back at the vehicle an ignition key and a boot key had ben taken.Police in Strangford have since been informed that a childrenrsquos sponsored walk was passing through the area at the time and they have appealed to parents to ask the children who took partthey know anything about the theft.NEWCASTLE mdash A burning interest in art has led Newcastle couple Margaret and Gerry Grant into an unusual project mdash the opening of a new art gallery in their own home.With over  paintings and sculptures of their own they have opened the gallery in an extension to their Bryansford Road house.But it isnrsquot only for the fun of it. The Grants will be buying and selling works and promoting exhibitions. Already they have lined up an autumn show with exhibits from a Spanish painter and an Italian sculptor.ldquoWe are aiming at the professional rather than the amateur, Mrs Grant said. ldquoOur main aim is to share our interest in art, but we do see the commercial and promotional sides to it.ldquoReally there is a wide range of work on show. My husband and I have been interested in art for a long time.DUNDRUM mdash A phantom clothes line thief has struck again mdash this time in Dundrum. The thief, who has been confining his acts to the Newcastle and Dundrum area, struck during the night at a house on the Dromara Road.A considerable number of childrenrsquos clothes were taken from the line, making it a profitable night for the thief.Police in Dundrum and Newcastle are anxious to catch the thief, who must have a considerable wardrobe stocked up by now. Anyone with information or who sees anyone acting suspiciously around houses at night should contact them immediately.KILLINCHY mdash Plans for a new primary school in Killinchy have brought a rsquono gorsquo sign from local residents. In a petition to the South Eastern Education and Library Board, the residents of Ardview Park have expressed serious concern about the plans.Itrsquos not the building of the school they object to, but rather the fact that access to the site will be off Ardview Park. They say they are concerned about traffic which will be using the road, both during the construction of the school and when it is opened.Their petition was recently shown to members of the Boardrsquos Finance Committee. Afterwards it was agreed to set up a special sub-committee to visit the school and report back on the plans.BALLYGOWAN mdash A Ballygowan housewe will be one of eight ladies who will be taking part in the national finals of the Cook of the Realm contest. Mrs Joy McVeigh baked her way through too the finals and now her efforts at the last hurdle will be televised on BBC next Wednesday.Mrs McVeigh and the seven other contestants will have to devise a fuel-saving meal for four people costing no more than pound and which must be cooked entirely in the oven or on top of the cooker. The top prize is valued at more than pound,.ARDGLASS mdash Ardglass boxer Ray Ross has been offered a wonderful chance to make an impact on the British lightweight scene.Every since he lost a close decision to Charlie Nash for the Irish title two years ago, the  year-old slugger has shown indferent form. But now the Ardglass golf course greenskeeper has a chance to make the top before he runs out of fight time and interest.Ross has been matched with the experienced Jonnie Elliott, of Bournemouth, over eight rounds at Maysfield Leisure Centre in Belfast on October  and a win would hoist Ross up the lightweight ladder and on to bigger punch for paydays.Ray is part of a big British title fight night involving Antrim southpaw Jim Montague against Clinton McKenzie for the vacant light welterweight title..prettyPhoto

title: Kilclief in full flow as ‘Fin are bottled up
story: A RESILIENT Kilclief outfit produced a rousing second half display to shatter Aughlisnafinrsquos championship dreams at St Colmanrsquos Park, Drumaness, on Saturday.Despite going into the break only - to - down, Kilclief were staring down the barrel of an ignoble defeat after losing the influential Louis McMullan and James McGrath to early black cards.To make matters even worse, they also lost the talismanic Ciaran Sloan to a hamstring injury and almost down to the bare bones, they looked vulnerable and there for the taking.However, led brilliantly by Aiden McCann and Eoin King they took the game to Aughlisnafin with a swagger and sparkle that Willie Megoranrsquos side were unable to contain.Aughlisnafin were impressively out of the traps first. Midfielder Eoin Lundy took the gamersquos first score before Ciaran Sloan levelled matters with a converted free. Unanswered points from the imposing Oran Flanagan, two frees and a rsquo, edged the lsquoFin into a deserved - to - lead by the seventh minute.It could have been even worse for Kilclief had Conall Magee not appeared from nowhere to block a certain Colm McVeigh goal with his foot.Lundy then made it a three-point game with a superlative score, but Kilclief, responded with points from Ciaran Sloan and Callum Shields after registering several wides.The lsquoFin finished the first half strongly and two more frees from Oran Flanagan gave them a - to - lead after  minutes. The last score of the half went to Kilcliefrsquos Dale Curran in the th minute to leave two points between the sides.Kilclief manager Dee King switched things round at the back for the start of the second half and this brought an immediate change in fortunes.Aughlisnafin were given fair warning of the maelstrom that was building up when Caelan Savage hit the woodwork after only  seconds of the restart and within minutes, points from Savage and Conor Sloan had the sides level.Aughlisnafin retaliated with a Sean Fitzsimmons goal against the run of play in the th minute, but two points from Caelan Savage left just a point between the sides by the th minute.Lundy and Shane Mooney extended Aughlisnafinrsquos lead to three points again, - to -, with  minutes remaining, but it was Kilclief who had a deadly sting in their tails.Caelan Savage was the lsquogo torsquo man and he delivered in style with a goal and a point to put Kilclief into the lead for the first time in the game and they never looked back after this.A Conor Sloan score and two points from lsquokeeper Ryan Miskelly, a rsquo and a long distance free, was the icing on the cake for Kilclief as they surged into the showdown with Teconnaught at Pairc Esler on October .   Kilclief: R Miskelly , Conor Hynds, A McCann, B Fitzsimons, D Merron, E King, C Savage , L McMullan, R McErlean, Conan Hynds, C Magee, Callum Shields , S Savage, J McGrath, Ciaran Sloan -f. Subs: E Breen for McMullan , D Curranfor McGrath , Conor Sloanfor Ciaran Sloan, S Cultra for Curran. Aughlisnafin: F Murphy, P McClean, J Brannigan, M Murdock, R Quinn, S McCann, S Willoughby, S Fitzsimmons , E Lundy , P Flanagan, O FlanaganR Murphy, J Matthews, S Mooney , C McVeigh.Kilclief -Aughlisnafin -PARADOR JFC SEMI-FINAL.prettyPhoto

title: Loughinisland seal league
story: LOUGHINISLAND secured a place in the top flight of Down football when coming out on top in a thrilling encounter against Longstone on Saturday.In the process they maintained their record of having won every league game to date in an action-packed encounter at the picturesque Mourne venue.The Blues got off to a great start with two points from the impressive Declan McClements, either side of one from Paddy McKenny which settled them into the game.It took ten minutes for Longstone to open their scoring when Michael Ireland slotted over the bar before getting his sidersquos second with a close range free. A Stefan Mason point put two between the sides, but Longstone were quick to answer when Conor Shields closed the gap to a point at the end of the first quarter.Declan McClements, Rory Mason and Stefan Mason added a further two points apiece with Aaron McClements scoring a superb point to cap a great first half for the visitors and help them to a six-points cushion.A brace of points from Mark Poland and an excellent score from Dean Haughian brought the lsquoStone back into contention, but they still trailed - to - as Ronan Barry blew for half-time.As expected, Longstone came out with a sense of purpose on the restart. A point by Stefan Mason was cancelled out by a similar score from Declan Magee for the home side. Jonny Flynn split the posts for the Blues, but Longstone were quick to reply with a close range free from Ireland.Two goals in two minutes for the home side meant they trailed by a single point and at this stage the game was anyones.However, Loughinislandrsquos recent senior championship campaign saw them battle-hardened and they stood tall to a man across the pitch as the Cloch Fhada men asked some serious questions going into the final quarter when they trailed by three points.Mark Poland and Rory Mason swapped scores and Declan McClements extended his sidersquos lead to four before Longstone hit back once again through former country star Poland.With six minutes to go and the game flowing from end to end, Conor Megoran picked up the ball on the right wing and sent it high into the Longstone square.Stefan Mason reacted quickest and with his back to goal shimmied to make space for a shot which flew past Michael McStay and into the back of the net.Longstone threw everything at the Bluesrsquo defence with Dan Gordon and Sean Cochrane combining to bravely block a certain goal-bound effort with Gordon taking a boot in the face for his troubles.Longstone knew it was not to be their day when Chris Turley denied them with a fantastic save to tip the ball over the bar with two minutes left on the clock.When they needed to dig deep, Loughinisland showed their true mettle. Having been rocked when conceding the two second half goals they steadied the ship with a defence led by Paddy Megoran, Dan Gordon, Jonny Flynn and Dean McLoughlin putting in a rousing last ten minutes when Longstone asked some serious questions.Declan McClements showed a stature beyond his youthful years in midfield, knocking over five points from play. Aaron McClements looked back to his old self with some magnicent high fielding which propelled his team forward throughout the  minutes.In the forward line Stefan Mason top-scored with - and alongside Conor Megoran and Rory Mason gave the Longstone defence plenty to think about with great support from Paddy McKenny, John McCarthy and Paul Digney.Loughinisland: C Turley, S Cochrane, P Megoran, C OrsquoToole, D McLoughlin , D Gordon, J Flynn , D McClements , A McClements , R Mason , P McKenny , P Digney, C Megoran, Stefan Mason , J McCarthy.Longstone -Loughinisland -ACFL DIVISION .prettyPhoto

title: Montalto estate visitor centre opens to public
story: THE spectacular Montalto estate in Ballynahinch has opened its doors to the public.Set in rolling drumlin countryside, people now have a wonderful opportunity to explore the historic estate including never-before seen gardens and picturesque trails.Montalto is a privately-owned demesne steeped in history dating back to the s. Famously, it is the site of lsquoThe Battle of Ballynahinchrsquo which took place during the Irish rebellion in  and is also home to an exotic plant collection initially created by lsquoThe father of Irish Gardeningrsquo, Sir Arthur Rawdon.There has been signicant investment at the estate over recent years which aims to reconnect visitors with nature through access to a range of captivating gardens and beautul walks and trails.The Wilson family, who run a range of businesses in Northern Ireland, originally used the manor house at the estate as an exclusive venue to host business clients but in  expanded into lsquoThe Carriage Roomsrsquo, a luxury wedding venue.As part of the ongoing business development strategy, the family decided that branching into tourism would support the sustainability of the estate.The investment mdash which has also provided the district with a signicant jobs boost mdash provides a new visitor experience that includes public access to the estatersquos beautul gardens with elements including many ieties of flora and fauna along with unique and surprising garden features.There are historic walks and trails and an exciting play area where children can explore, learn and wonder at their natural surroundings.A purpose built centre, designed in keeping with the look and feel of the estate, includes a welcome area featuring interpretation of the estatersquos history, a stylish  seat cafeacute offering flavoursome and beautully presented food and a shop that offers a mix of estate produce, local craft products and many other unique and exceptionally designed items.The beautul features include an alpine, winter, cutting, walled and formal gardens and the orchard situated within a wildflower meadow.In addition, four champion trees are located around the lake and the pinetum and over the past three years over , trees have been planted on the estate.Active families will enjoy the woodland trail and low wood with the impressive purpose-built treehouse, which was handcrafted on-site, featuring rope bridges, monkey barsand treetop views kids of all ages will enjoy.Mini explorers can enjoy the smaller treehouse and natural play area. Everything within this area has been designed to fuel the imagination through exploration and discovery.For tranquil and picturesque walks, visitors can enjoy the stunning views of The Lake Walk and The Garden Walk and catch a glimpse of some of the wonderful wildle that calls Montalto estate home, or simply take in the beautul seasonal displays and reconnect with nature.As part of the visitor experience, guests will discover the history and heritage of the estate through the informative interpretation in the welcome area, browse the stylish retail space or have a bite to eat in The Cafeacute at Montalto which has been lovingly designed to capture the essence of the estate as well as offering great tasting food.Montalto estatersquos managing director, David Wilson, said its opening to visitors marks a very special moment in its history.ldquoFor the first time, we are inviting people to step inside, explore our walks and trails and discover for themselves the magnicence of this beautul site, he explained.ldquoOur dedicated team has worked hard to create a very special visitor experience and are looking forward to welcoming everyone to enjoy their time with us. We hope Montalto estate will become the perfect complement to the Northern Ireland tourism portfolio and we look forward to sharing details of further developments at the estate in the future.Mr Wilson said by opening the estate to visitors, the owners are ensuring that they help to secure the preservation of Montaltorsquos long and fascinating history for future generations to enjoy.ldquoWe hope visitors will get as much enjoyment from Montalto as our family has over the years. When visitors step inside and explore Montalto, we hope that they will want to keep coming back, added Mr Wilson.The estatesrsquos opening hours are Wednesday to Sunday, am until pm, with access to the site including car park, welcome area, cafeacute and shop is free.Gardens, trails and walks will be ticketed with prices starting from pound. for adults and pound for children aged between five and . Children under five are admitted free, with discounted rates available via online booking. Visit www.montaltoestate or follow the estate on Facebook, Twitter and Instagram #exploremontalto..prettyPhoto

title: Pierce heads to Australia
story: A YOUNG Saul Gaelic footballer has just jetted off to Australia to compete for a potential Aussie Rules professional contract.Under the expert guidance of former Down and AFL star Marty Clarke,  year-old Pierce Laverty has successfully secured a ticket to Melbourne for a series of trials.Pierce will get a week to train and acclimatise before testing starts on October  in goal kicking, skills, agility, time-trials and jump tests.All the big AFL clubs will be observing the training and testing week and will select players who they think are good enough to make it.Typically, Pierce is taking this opportunity in his stride, and itrsquos his combination of skill, athleticism and attitude that has set him apart.Unfortunately, Pierce will miss Saulrsquos Parador Lodge IFC semi-final clash with Bredagh in Newry on Saturday night, but hersquos hoping his team-mates can make it through without him and that he will be home in time for the final..prettyPhoto

title: Resolve over Brexit is required%2C says MP
story: BREXIT topped the agenda during a meeting in Dublin last week attended by South Down MP Chris Hazzard.He was joined for the meeting at the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade in Dublin by Senator Niall Oacute Donnghaile, with the focus of the talks shining a spotlight on the ongoing Brexit negotiations and possible impact on future trading arrangements across Ireland, Britain, and Europe.Mr Hazzard said at this ldquocritical juncture in the Brexit negotiations, it is vital there are strong, informed voices at the table making the case for local communities, businesses and the protection of citizensrsquo rights going forward.He continued: I want to thank officials for engaging constructively on these issues and committing to continue this engagement in the time ahead.ldquoIn the face of bewildering deflection and heightening rhetoric from Downing Street, the Irish Government and the European Union must remain resolute.Mr Hazzard added: ldquoThey must remain true to their word that without an agreed, legally enforceable lsquobackstop,rsquo there will be no withdrawal agreement..prettyPhoto

title: Sam Rutherford Cup belongs to St Patrick’s
story: ST Patrickrsquos Golf Club are the proud holders of the Sam Rutherford Cup.Saturday and Sunday witnessed the clash of the titans as St Patrickrsquos took on neighbours Rockmount in the two-leg final.The first leg was played at St Patrickrsquos in ideal conditions for golf with a light breeze and sunny conditions.Rockmount had chosen to play away from home as they had enjoyed good results from this tactic in previous rounds. However, St Patrickrsquos were not going to be complacent in their approach and fully recognised the quality of their opponents.St Patrickrsquos had the right blend of youth and experience and the games were played with great spirit and determination.The first pairing of James Kernoghan and Pearse Tumelty succumbed to the power and precision of Rockmountrsquos top pairing and lost out by two holes.Pocket rockets Gary Murrayand Ed Baggley Jr were second out and played their usual power game with the addition of sublime putting finesse to win by two holes.The third pairing of Paddy Totton and Gary Murraydelivered the killer blow to Rockmount and romped home by four holes.Their tenacity and resilience proved to be the foundation for the rest of the team. The last pairing of the rock steady Adrian Magee and Declan Dowie continued their unbeaten run in the competition, winning by one hole.The players from St Patrickrsquos did their club proud by winning the first leg with five holes up. Although this was a slender lead to take to Rockmount, the confidence of the lads to deliver away from home remained.For theleg at Rockmount conditions were much more dficult with a swirling wind and occasional showers.The St Patrickrsquos opening pair was Totton mdash the lsquodaddy of the team mdash and the Strangford Murray. They played some sublime golf with Totton driving like a professional and the silky putting skills of Murray resulting in them winning their match by one hole. This again laid the foundation by beating Rockmountrsquos top pairing.Up next were the Crossgar Murray and Baggley Jr, who played like giants and produced some phenomenal golf against great opponents to win by one hole.The third pairing of Tumelty and Kernoghan proved their worth with the superb driving ability of Kernoghan combined with the steady chipping and unflappable putting of Tumelty resulting in a halved match.The final pairing of the mercurial Magee and Dowie proved once again how the youth of the team held no fears and played with complete passion and energy, never allowing any dips in performance to unravel their steely determination to win. They eventually won by two holes, birdieing the last two in an amazing cauldron of pressure.The match was played with great sportsmanship by both clubs and Rockmount were most gracious in defeat.St Patrickrsquos club captain Michael Donovan and team Captain Brendan Mullen were delighted to receive the pennant and cup from Dave Allen..prettyPhoto

title: Stephanie’s photo with Meghan now a royal thank you
story: THE Duchess of Sussex has a lot to thank Comber woman Stephanie Jordan for.A press photographer captured a beautul moment when the former television star Meghan Markle spotted Stephanie and her friends in the crowd during a visit with Prince Harry to Dublin in July.The image from Irish Independent photographer Gerry Mooney was then used for a Royal thank-you card sent out to all who wished the Duchess well on her recent birthday.Since Stephanie wore her lsquoWhen Harry Met Meghanrsquo T-shirt to greet the Royal couple, her le has been ldquoquite surreal.The  year-old health service administrative officer said that apart from receiving a thank-you card from the Duchess, the image of them both smiling at one another has been published throughout the world.She has also appeared on the Ray DrsquoArcy radio show and TV show on RTE.ldquoItrsquos all been quite surreal but wonderful and great fun and something to be treasured, said Stephanie.ldquoI had never really been to a Royal visit before but after my friend and I celebrated Harry and Meghanrsquos wedding with our T-shirts on at an afternoon tea party, when we heard they were coming to Dublin we decided to go and see them.Having earlier sussed out that Trinity College was the ideal place to get close to the Royal couple, Stephanie was delighted when their distinctive T-shirts grabbed the Duchessrsquos attention as she presented her a small bouquet of flowersldquoMeghan shook our hands and said thank you for coming, said Stephanie. ldquoI told her it was worth getting up at am for and she asked where I was from. I said we travelled from Belfast and she said she really appreciated the effort we had gone to. She was really lovely and very natural.However, after the meeting, Gerry Mooneyrsquos photograph seemed to capture the spirit of the day and was used in daily Irish papers as well as in glossy magazines since such as Vogue, Cosmopolitan and Elle.Stephanie said she had always admired Meghan Markle since seeing her in the US drama series Suit.However, her fascination grew when her romance with Prince Harry first broke and grew with the engagement, followed by the wedding in May.ldquoIrsquove always loved Prince Harry as he seems to be just a really genuine, lovely friendly person who has time for everyone and very like his mother.ldquoItrsquos just so lovely to see him so happy and I definitely will try and see him and Meghan again in the future..prettyPhoto

title: Storm Ali batters district
story: STORM Ali, which battered the district last week, left its devastating imprint, with trees brought down across a huge area.Predictably, the local coastline took a battering as the storm barrelled in last Wednesday, with Newcastle leboat volunteers taking to the sea at the height of the storm to go to the aid of a stricken yacht on Strangford Lough.Large trees came crashing down across the district during the storm which claimed the le of man working at a pumping station at Slieve Gullion Forest Park.There were no reports of major power outages, but roads officials were left with a major operation to reopen a number of main routes blocked by fallen trees.Some of the most powerful images captured during last weekrsquos storm were of the Newcastle leboat crew as they left their base at the townrsquos harbour to make their way to Strangford Lough.The alert was raised at .am to go the aid of a stricken yacht at Newtownards Sailing Club on the lough. The all-weather leboat under coxswain William Chambers launched within minutes into the middle of Storm Ali as it unleashed its devastating power.The challenging weather conditions the crew was going to face en route to Newtownards were immediately apparent after launch, with the coxswain requesting the closure of main water tight doors as the vessel was battered by eight metre high waves.A Force  gale was blowing as the crew approached Strangford Lough some  minutes after the seas started to settle as the leboat was sheltered by the shore.On arrival at the yacht club, the Coastguard was concerned that there may be a person on board the weather beaten vessel, but it was subsequently confirmed there wasnrsquot.The leboat was then requested to go the aid of another yacht drting across the lough from Whiterock and Kircubbin. Unfortunately, by the time the leboat reached the vessel there was nothing the crew could do as it was on the rocks on an ebbing tide.As the leboat made herjourney to Newcastle and was approaching Portaferry, the crew were alerted to another yacht in dficulty. The crew established a tow line and managed to free the vessel and towed it to the safety off a mooring in Strangford marina.Theto Newcastle was another hazardous journey as the crew battled mountainous seas, forcing the vessel to stop at Ardglass marina for an hour to allow the storm force wind to ease and the waves to decrease. The leboat left the marina at pm, ing home one hour later.ldquoThis was a challenging day for our volunteers given that we launched into rough seas when Storm Ali was at its worst, said Coxswain William Chambers when safely back ashore. ldquoOur volunteers are highly skilled and trained for these situations and were delighted to be able to help.Some of the largest trees to fall victim to last weekendrsquos storm have been a prominent landmark in Castlewellanrsquos Lower Square for generations.Slieve Croob councillor Roiacutesiacuten Howell believes the location of the fallen trees should be the future home of the townrsquos permanent Christmas tree.ldquoLike many other residents who have grown up in the area their whole le, I was saddened to see these two great trees blow down. In many ways, they were local landmarks that were an iconic part of the heritage of our market town, standing for well over two hundred years, she said.ldquoI have proposed that the local council should consider placing Castlewellanrsquos new permanent live Christmas tree at this location. This would be a permanent feature all year round and save the council thousands of pounds every year.Cllr Howell added: ldquoThis idea is still a very early proposal, but as Castlewellan is one of seven towns within the district to have been chosen to have a live Christmas tree, I feel council officials should consider it as a good way of making use of this new space and will hopefully in time become our new local landmark..prettyPhoto

title: Tourism proposal showcased at Italian conference
story: PROPOSALS to secure a world renowned tourism designation for an area stretching from Strangford Lough to South Armagh were outlined to  delegates at a prestigious international conference in Italy recently.Newry, Mourne and Down Council is seeking prestigious UNESCO geopark status for an area taking in the Mournes, Ring of Gullion and the Strangford and Lecale Areas of Outstanding Natural Beauty.A steering committee has been established to spearhead the bid which is in its very early stages, with the formal application to secure geopark status not expected to be submitted until November next year.Those behind the ambitious plan insist securing geopark status is primarily about environmental sustainability and, at the same time, trying to increase economic revenue in a part of the world already revered for its stunning beauty.The emphasis moving forward is on partnership and engaging with local communities, with the steering group keen to talk to as many people as possible. The local council was recently represented at the eighth international conference on UNESCO global geoparks in Italy.Senior UNESCO officials, scientists, policy makers, government representatives and local communities from across the globe gathered at the Adamello Brento geopark to discuss sustainable development and the activities of the global geopark network.During the event, Newry, Mourne and Down Council and the Geological Survey of Northern Irelandpresented an abstract on the proposed geopark in the Mournes area.Local authority chairman, Mark Murnin, said the conference provided an excellent  to share the story of the aspiring Two Oceans Geopark proposal for the local area to an international audience.In addition, he said the event provided a chance to highlight the rich geology of the region as well as the benefits geopark status will provide to the area through geotourism.ldquoThis was an excellent occasion which allowed us to network and exchange innovative and best practice approaches with geoparks around the world, Cllr Murnin added.Since March last year, the local authorityrsquos aspiring geopark project team, in partnership with GSNI, has undertaken delivery of an intensive communications plan to spell out the proposal, while over the coming months there will be a programme of educational activities held across the council area.Geoparks are based around signicant areas of geology and are set up to support sustainable economic development of an area, primarily through geological and eco-tourism. But they are not just about geology and include sites that are of interest for their history, archaeology, bioersity, folklore, cultural and local heritage.Securing the prestigious designation is one of the key planks of Newry, Mourne and Down Councilrsquos tourism strategy.The current focus is on firming up the boundaries of the proposed geopark with those involved in compiling the UNESCO designation confident it has the potential to deliver high quality tourism in the area, increasing the number of international visitors.The local authority is exploring the tourism potential associated with securing geopark status, with officials insisting there is a signicant financial benefit for securing it, with the benefits not just economic.Officials believe geoparks have a signicant role to play in empowering local communities and giving them the opportunities to develop cohesive partnerships with the common goal of promoting the arearsquos signicant geological and other heritage.There are currently  geoparks found in  countries across the world, all of which have been developed using a bottom-up approach with local communities playing a signicant role in this process.However, the global geopark brand does not impose any restrictions on farming practices, planning or development.Further information on the geopark proposal is available via Facebook on Geotourism in Mourne, Gullion and Strangford or for specic queries email geopark@nmandd.org..prettyPhoto
